That the Commonwealth Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 could be used to support the provision by the Commonwealth of funding, counselling, etc. for deliberately procured abortions.

And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

petition.title: Sex Discrimination Legislation
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 contains provisions inconsistent with principles of justice and equality which could be used to:
Undermine civil liberties and religious freedoms;
Entrench abortion funding and render liable to action hospitals, doctors and nurses, who conscientiously refuse to become involved in morally objectionable operations;
Deny to parents their rights to insist the school 'community' provide an environment conducive to the development, including moral development of their children.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled; should amend the Bill so as to prevent the possibility of its use in the manner stated above and urge, because of the importance to society of all principles involved, that a conscience vote on the Bill be permitted to all members of Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

petition.title: Discrimination against Women
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that whereas the Government of Australia has signed the United Nations Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which in Article 23 (1) states that 'The family is the natural and fundamental group unit of society and is entitled to the protection by society and the State', and
Whereas the terms of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women would violate the above Article 23 (1).
We humbly pray the Government to refrain from ratifying the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women; Believing that its implementation would result in:
(1) Undue cost to the nation at this time.

(2) 'The elimination of any stereotyped concept of roles of men and women at all levels' as described in Part 3 Article 10 (c), being a disruption of traditional parental roles, is likely to result in emotional disturbances of childhood.

(3) The strong encouragements to mothers to join the workforce, with the provision of networks of creches and child care centres as outlined in article 11 of the convention is likely to result in maternal deprivation and psychological disturbances among children with an increase in childhood psychiatric illnesses.
(4) The sexual role changing as recommended in Part 3 Article 10 (c) is likely to contribute to further marriage insecurity and breakdown.
And we pray you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our nation
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

petition.title: Education
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens, teachers and parents working in and for the interests of the pupils in government schools and colleges throughout Australia respectfully sheweth that:
1. We fully support the Federal Government's actions in reducing funds for the wealthiest private schools, and in breaking the nexus between government and non -government school costs.

2. We endorse the Federal Government's principled opposition to the provision of 'base grants' to all non-government schools, as a positive step towards fulfilling their commitment of primary obligation to Australia's government schools.

3. We call upon the Federal Government, however, to recognise that its failure to create an adequate general recurrent resource base for government schools through providing increased recurrent grants, will undermine its own special programs and thus frustrate its own stated educational objectives of greater equity and participation.

4. We support the Federal Government's stated policy of entering into direct negotiations for joint agreements on these grants with State/Territory Governments, to ensure a planned program of improvements in government schools throughout the coming decade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

petition.title: Medicare
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
That, with the exception of the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory, all State Parliaments have enacted chiropractic legislation.
That chiropractors provide a safe, effective and economical health care service that is complementary to medicine.

That the introduction of a Federally-funded health care system restricted to the services provided almost exclusively by the medical profession restricts the freedom to select the health care practitioner of one's choice.
That a financial disadvantage will be incurred by those citizens utilising chiropractic care, many of whom find that their health complaints do not resond satisfactorily to traditional approaches.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled ensures that chiropractic services are included in Medicare when it is introduced.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

petition.title: Mr Mart Niklus
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

(1) That we are deeply concerned for the well-being of Mr Mart Niklus, a leading Estonian and Baltic human rights activist who is in ill health and imprisoned in solitary confinement in Perm Labour Camp No. 389/36 in Siberia.
(2) That Mr Mart Niklus has been imprisoned as a 'prisoner of conscience' for the non-violent exercise of his beliefs and is denied visiting and communication rights.

(3) That the Australian Government give its support to any initiatives in this case by Amnesty International which has adopted Mr Mart Niklus. Amnesty International believes he has committed no real crime and has never used or advocated the use of violence.
(4) That we urge the Australian Government to make representations to the Government of the Soviet Union to promptly release Mr Mart Niklus and grant him a passport and exit visa.
(5) That in its representations to the Government of the Soviet Union advise that the Australian Government has approved the sponsored entry of Mr Mart Niklus into Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

petition.title: Plant Variety Rights
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government

1. Uphold the principle that the seeds and cuttings of plants are a public resource and a common heritage to all and that accordingly seeds should be freely available to all, freely multipliable, able to be sold, exchanged, exported and imported by anyone who wishes. This is seen as a matter of national food security.

2. Recognize that plant breeding is a highly co-operative venture often involving private enterprise at the very last stages after basic seed collection , storage, and research has been publicly funded.
3. In view of the aforementioned paragraphs, recognise that any system giving ' property' or ownership rights over seeds to invididuals, organisations or enterprises is inappropriate and unjust.
4. Recognise that legislation establishing plant patenting schemes overseas has had serious adverse effects namely:
i. a slowing-down of scientific information exchange and exchanges in basic plant breeding materials, that is, germ plasm,
ii. subordination and/or curtailment of public breeding programmes,
iii. farmer unrest at seed prices,
iv. monopoly control of seed production and sales has passed into the hands of giant petrochemical and drug corporations also marketing cropchemicals,
v. increased uniformity of crop varieties leading to a vulnerability to pest and disease attack.
5. Reject any proposal to legislate for any system such as the drafted Plant Variety Rights Act, which gives exclusive ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

question.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: —Did the Attorney-General or anyone acting on his behalf change the Hansard typescript of an answer to the question that I asked him on Friday concerning ministerial responsibility over the Australian Secret Intelligence Service incident at the Sheraton Hotel by the addition of the word 'always'?

answer.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: —As I recall, I did make a minor amendment or two, as is common--

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting-

talk.start.para: —As is perfectly common for all honourable senators in this place, provided that, in doing so, one does not change the meaning, the substance or the context in which the answer is given.
—A very good proviso.

—I am very puzzled that there should be indignation on this subject. It is a well known practice in this place to be given 'pinks' for the very purpose of clarifying some things which get confused from time to time. I thought it was perfectly clear, and if honourable senators will refer to the answer in question in Hansard, they will see that the answer that I gave with respect to this was perfectly clear, that it is and was my belief that the principle to which Senator Sir John Carrick was referring did have application, and that whenever an issue arose possibly justifying an application of that principle, it would be appropriate for the Ministers concerned, in those situations, to look to the circumstances of the particular case and to give anxious consideration as to whether the principle was breached. That was the point I was making. The context in which I was making it was perfectly clear, as I indicated in my personal explanation on Friday, and in reading that personal explanation I was reading from an amended copy of the Hansard in question.
—Yes, you sure were.

—The punctuation, as I recall, because I made a particular point of it in my personal explanation, was somewhat obscure in this particular respect and in fact it obscured a context that was perfectly clear in the language that I actually used and in the hearing of all listeners except those ill motivated points-scorers opposite who seek to derive more than can possibly be derived from the record.
—You are a disgrace.
—I take the opportunity, in between Senator Chaney's interjections, to make the point--
—Cheat!
—As I made it on Friday--
—Order! I would ask the Leader of the Opposition to withdraw that remark.
—I withdraw, Mr President.

—I make the point, as I made on Friday, that there is no question whatsoever of a belief or a skerrick of a belief in my mind that this is an appropriate case for Mr Hayden even to consider resigning. The nature of the blunder in question, spectacular as it was within the organisation, was not of a kind comparable with earlier occasions that have given rise to debate, hypocritical as it may be on this occasion, from honourable senators opposite. Moreover, the point needs to be made, and needs to be reiterated very forcefully , that Mr Hayden's reaction to those circumstances when they came to his knowledge was swift, effective and sensible in the extreme, and, indeed, has not been challenged on either side of this place and has, moreover, been specifically endorsed by the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Peacock, who said that he found Mr Hayden's reaction absolutely impeccable in all the circumstances and one that he would have followed himself.

answer.para: I cannot see the force of the point that is endeavouring to be made on the other side. It is a demonstration of the moral and intellectual bankruptcy, not to mention the political bankruptcy, of what honourable senators opposite have to offer.

question.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Does the Attorney-General assert, from his answer, that the addition of the word 'always' to his answer was a minor and inconsequential change that did not change the meaning of the words, and not an alteration--

question.para: Government senators interjecting-

talk.start.para: —Order! I cannot hear the question.

—I ask the Attorney-General: Did he, by his answer, assert that the addition of the word 'always' to his answer last week meant only a minor and inconsequential amendment which would not alter the meaning, and not a substantial alteration which did in fact alter wholly the meaning?

answer.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: —Yes, I do so assert, vigorously and strongly. There was no question of the meaning, the substance or the context in any way being altered, and indeed, were there such a suggestion, I would have expected the Hansard reporters or supervisor to come to me and say: 'To do this is not in accordance with the practice of this place'. Some of us are less honour bound than others when it comes to these matters, but all of us are honour bound to observe the conventions of this place and not to amend the written record in any way.

answer.para: Senator Lewis interjecting-

talk.start.para: —Order! Senator Lewis.
—Senator Lewis has something to withdraw, I understand, Mr President.
—Senator Lewis, I ask you to withdraw your remarks.
—What did I say, Mr President?
—I shall not repeat it. I ask you to withdraw.
—Whatever it was, no doubt it will be recorded in Hansard. I withdraw.

—I think I have completed the point I wanted to make. There was no change whatsoever in substance. Had there been a change of substance or something as to render the context or the impression to be derived from the answer different, I would have expected that matter to be drawn to my attention. It was not.
—I raise a point of personal explanation, Mr President. I have recalled that the expression I used was 'Rubbish'. I now withdraw the word ' Rubbish', but I do not think it was unparliamentary.

—My question is addressed to you, Mr President. I noticed last week that the portraits of former Senator Dorothy Tangey and Dame Enid Lyons had been moved to either side of the Library doors, and I was pleased that this action had occurred as I understood it was in response to questions in this chamber from Senator Coleman. To my surprise, I notice that the portraits are now back behind the pillars. Mr President, can you explain why the two portraits in question have been moved again, as it seemed to me that they adorned the Library entrance and the top of King's Hall with grace and elegance?

—The two portraits were first moved without authority about three weeks ago. Because the Speaker and I had had discussions with the Joint House Department about rotation of portraits and it had been reported to the House Committee that arrangements were being made for rotation of all portraits during the forthcoming parliamentary recess and because the portraits were moved without the authority of the Speaker and me, it was decided that they should be returned to their original positions. The instruction that has been given to the Joint House Department for rotation will apply to all portraits, not just the two referred to by the honourable senator, and will take effect during the forthcoming parliamentary recess.

question.speaker: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

talk.start.para: —My question is also directed to the Attorney-General. I refer to the words which he used in answer to Senator Sir John Carrick's question last Friday. This is the relevant section of what he actually said, not as it is recorded in Hansard--
—Huh!
—I understand that Senator Evans agrees that what he actually said is different from what is now recorded in Hansard. This is what the Attorney said:

question.para: Of course, it is a question of interpretation, in all the circumstances of a particular case, of what is a minor blunder of real importance to Australia and no doubt some anxious consideration will be given to the proper application of that criterion by the Ministers concerned.
Is not any reasonable listener to that answer entitled to believe that the Attorney-General was referring to the particular incident itself and the Ministers concerned?

answer.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: —No, I do not accept that. I have now obtained a copy of the question and the answer. The question was about what I thought of the continuing application of the Fraser principle which I had endorsed against the Opposition last year. It was a fair question, a neat question and one which I applauded as such, and I began my answer as follows:

answer.para: Being not imbued with the same collection of double standards that afflict the Opposition, nor the same capacity for situation ethics, as I think the theologians describe it, I do still endorse the force of that principle which I sought to articulate last year on no less an authority, as I invoked, than Mr Malcolm Fraser.
I then went on straightaway to the sentence quoted:

Of course, it is a question of interpretation, in all the circumstances of a particular case-not, I add for the record, this particular case but a particular case-of what is a major blunder of real importance to Australia and no doubt some anxious consideration will always be given-
will be given or will always be given, as one's taste takes one-
to the proper application of that criterion by the Ministers concerned.

I said 'Ministers', plural, as I emphasised at the time in answer to a supplementary question. I then said something to the effect of it being ' intolerable that we should be subjected, on occasions like this, to the kind of hypocrisy that now wafts across from the Opposition benches'. That hypocrisy, I add, wafts again in increasing gusts today. I said nothing about the circumstances of this particular case. Indeed, it was my belief and knowledge at the stage when I answered that question that only one Minister had been involved , namely, Mr Hayden, and that there was no question of any other Minister, other than Mr Scholes in telling him, being involved. It was only one Minister with ministerial responsibility, as indeed is still my belief. I would not have answered a question in terms of any possibility of another Minister being involved.

The whole context of that answer, to repeat endlessly, referred to the general application from time to time of the principle which appealed to Mr Malcolm Fraser in his day but which manifestly did not appeal to this lot when they were in government last year, for perfectly understandable reasons, but ones no less redolent of hypocrisy for that. I do not think there is anything more I can say except that, in answer to a supplementary question, I was pressed on the circumstances of this case. I chose not to answer that question. That is, of course, what gave rise to the allegations of ambiguity which I then corrected in a personal explanation later in the afternoon. I repeat that this attack today is a demonstration of the moral, intellectual and political bankruptcy of the Opposition party in this nation and an ample demonstration of everything that we have been asserting to this effect for months on end.

talk.start.para: —I direct a question to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. It is prompted by an article in the Brisbane Sunday Mail last weekend. The article dealt with the proposed assets test and indicated that disability pensions will be assessed as income in determining eligibility for an age pension. As many service pensioners thought this also referred to their pensions, will the Minister advise whether disability pensions will continue to be exempt in determining eligibility for a service pension?

answer.speaker: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

talk.start.para: —Since the Government announced its proposal in respect of the assets test, and more particularly in the last week or so, there have been numerous articles in most of the popular newspapers commenting upon the decision and giving advice to pensioners, whether they be age and invalid pensioners or service pensioners. Both Senator Grimes and I have examined those statements very carefully because that advice has been made available to people in good faith by the writers of the newspapers. I must say that in an overwhelming majority of cases we have found no reasons to doubt their interpretation given in good faith in the articles.

answer.para: However, I am afraid that there has been a misunderstanding by the writer of that article in the Sunday Mail of last Sunday. It is true that war disability pensions are assessed as income in determining eligibility for pensions under the Social Services Act. To that extent, the article has some particular validity or relevance. However, war disability pensions are not and will not be treated as income in determining eligibility for service pensions. So, in fact, two different standards are applied. The Repatriation Act for which I am responsible is quite clear on this point, that disability pensions are compensatory pensions, not welfare related measures, and are paid irrespective of means. That, of course, will continue whatever happens in respect of the assets test unless, of course, some capricious amendment is adopted in the Senate.

However, the Government is concerned that that application of policy to service pensions does not apply in respect of age and invalid pensions, those that fall within the ministerial jurisdiction of my colleague, Senator Grimes. The Government is concerned with a long-standing anomaly whereby disability pensions are treated as income under the Social Services Act. That is a practice and procedure that has existed for many many years and has not, at this stage, been picked up by this Government. However, the appropriate Ministers will be examining a case for removing this anomaly but will do so in respect of the 1984 -85 Budget.

question.speaker: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

talk.start.para: — I ask the Attorney-General: Did he or his office have any contact with either the Prime Minister or the Foreign Minister concerning the Attorney's answer to Senator Sir John Carrick prior to the decision to add the word 'always' to the Attorney's answer as recorded by Hansard last Friday?
—The answer is no.

—My question is to the Minister for Social Security. It refers to the handicapped programs review and its reference to the accountability of organisations that assist disabled persons. Can the Minister advise whether any submissions to the review have related to the lack of liberty and privacy in nursing homes and institutions where disabled persons live or work? Does the Minister agree that, where the Government allocates specific purpose grants to certain social welfare organisations, those organisations should be required to account for the quality of service they provide?

answer.speaker: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

talk.start.para: —Under the handicapped programs review now being conducted we have received in excess of 900 submissions. As is inevitable in this area, some submissions refer to the lack of privacy and personal liberty alleged against some organisations which conduct nursing homes and similar accommodation facilities for the disabled. This has been an issue over many years, as I am sure Senator Elstob will know. Honourable senators will realise that the Government's policy is to assist organisations to provide the least restrictive alternative to those who are disabled, and part of that least restrictive alternative is obviously the protection of liberty and privacy for disabled people in such accommodation. Some months ago I put out a statement pointing out to organisations that we will be considering present applications as well as past applications in the light of this principle of the least restrictive environment and that we will be reluctant to fund organisations that are restrictive in this way.

answer.para: Organisations have limited disabled people's privacy in many ways, from the point of view of mere personal privacy, by not providing individual rooms or rooms where people can be private with friends or others, and of some organisations that restrict the liberty, one could say, of parents of disabled people by insisting that only the children of those parents who are willing to contribute certain funds or certain hours of work to the organisations will have their children looked after. I hope that in the future these restrictive practices will cease, and I know in some organisations they are already ceasing. We will be interested to see how many submissions we get as regards this aspect of the care of the disabled but we are certainly determined to make sure that in future that very important principle of the least restrictive environment does apply.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Attorney-General. I remind him of what he had to say in the adjournment debate last Friday. Does he agree that in accusing me of misrepresenting him, both during that debate and in a subsequent Press statement, he based his charge on a doctored quotation which did not actually represent what he had said earlier in the day? As I have since listened to the Hansard tape recording and it is quite obvious that the word ' always' was never used by the Attorney, will he now take action to restore the record to the truth? Will he also withdraw the allegations he made against me and apologise, as it is now quite clear that it is he, not me, who is guilty of fabrication, to quote his own term of abuse?

answer.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: —No, I do not agree that there was any misrepresentation on my part. There was some confusion in the way the punctuation recorded what I recalled my utterance to be. I wanted to put the matter beyond doubt but I believe, as I have read into the record again today, the context in which I was giving that answer does put it beyond doubt. As to Senator Chaney's Sherlock Holmes or post-Watergate endeavours in listening to tapes and so on, I congratulate him for his stamina and enthusiasm but remind him I made no suggestion in anything I have said today that I did in fact use that word. I made the point today that I was simply putting that word in the record in order to clarify the context because I thought the context had become confused by the punctuation that had been employed and that the sense, the meaning, the context, were utterly changed and that it would have been improper for me to have changed the sense, the meaning or the context, but it is not at all improper, of course, to change particular language.

answer.para: I make the further point that under no circumstances will I apologise or withdraw any imputations or allegations made in respect of Senator Chaney's behaviour in this matter. I described it in terms which I was obliged to withdraw on Friday. The record is there. That record speaks for itself. I will not apologise and I believe it is still incumbent on Senator Chaney himself to do that.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question in light of the Attorney-General's suggestion that the record is straight. I ask him again: Will he correct the record and ensure that the words actually used by him appear in the Hansard? I welcome the use of the word 'Watergate' by him because I think the analogy is quite a good one. I remind him of what happened to President Nixon over the tapes.
—Order! I would ask the Leader of the Opposition to ask his question.

—I ask him on what basis he insists that the record should not be changed when he admits the words as they appear in Hansard are not the words he used. He has added the word which has been referred to in this question.

—Mr President, I will not make any such alteration of the Hansard record. I believe it is entirely consistent with the practice in this place employed by all honourable senators, or at least those of us who from time to time bother to look at our 'pinks', in fact to make corrections of grammar and other linguistic usages such as may from time to time be necessary to clarify the particular language or the particular point that is being made. I would be very surprised indeed if any honourable senator in this place has not at some stage or another made some such similar clarification, if only to pull the written record out of the linguistic mess in which the oral contribution may well have left it.

—Can the Minister for Industry and Commerce, who I understand handles Customs matters, confirm that an officer of the Department of Foreign Affairs was detected illegally importing a machine gun into Australia at the time Mr John Ryan was First Assistant Secretary to the Department of Foreign Affairs? Was there a cover-up of that matter? Will the Minister provide to the Senate full details of that and any subsequent like incidents?

—If there were a cover-up of that matter I certainly would not be able to answer the question either now or at any time in the future. I have no information as to whether an officer of the Department of Foreign Affairs was illegally importing a machine gun. I will make some inquiries and if there is not a cover-up I will get an answer to the question and I will give it to Senator Primmer as soon as possible.

—Is the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women aware of recent Press reports, specifically in last night's edition of the Adelaide News, which indicate that South Australian women's shelters will be ' grossly underfunded' under a new Federal funding formula which allocates an extra $4m of funds according to criteria which do not include need? Is this allegation correct? If it is correct can the Minister say why the Government is abandoning its election commitment to the thousands of women and children who are in need of the sort of crisis care provided by the women's shelters in South Australia? If it is not correct can the Minister say what criteria will be used for the allocation of those funds and whether she believes that the $50,000 which is allegedly to be South Australia's share will be sufficient to met the needs of already inadequate salaries and conditions for staff as well as the ongoing costs for women in crisis care?

answer.speaker: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

talk.start.para: —Although the administration of the new women's emergency services program is the responsibility of my colleague the Minister for Social Security, I can confirm for Senator Haines that the report she refers to in the South Australian newspaper is quite wrong, I think wrong in all details except for the fact that an extra $4m has been allocated by the Federal Government for the first year of implementing our women's emergency services program.

answer.para: The program will be administered in co-operation with the States and it is hoped that the Commonwealth's decision to allocate an extra $4m to this very important, and badly under-resourced area, will be met by increased allocations from States where that is possible. I point out to the Senate that different States made different levels of effort with respect to supporting refuges during the period of the Fraser Administration when Federal support was withdrawn. I know from continuous dealings with the South Australian Government and with women working in refuges in South Australia that the South Australian Government in recent years has been very conscientious in terms of resources, housing and so forth that it makes available for the women's refuge program.

The Commonwealth has attached a number of guidelines to the expenditure of the $4m. One of the important ones is that it should assist the payment of award wages to refuge workers. As I am sure Senator Haines is aware, most refuge workers are working for well below award wages. They often work for very long hours six or sometimes seven days a week. As a result, they become quite exhausted and it is extremely difficult for them to deliver the standard of service we would like women and children who are seeking refuge to attract. So we have as a priority the raising of wages to award levels.

The other priority we have is the funding of new services in areas of need. Although, of course, all refuges are in areas of need, there are many areas of high need which have no refuges at all. So, that part of the money which will be available for new programs will be available for new projects in areas of need. However, the detailed sharing out of the $4m and the negotiations with the States as to what they can contribute over and above what they have already been contributing is the responsibility of the Department of Social Security. I understand that those negotiations are now under way. I am sure that if Senator Haines would like more detailed information about the negotiations with her State of South Australia officers from Senator Grimes's office would be able to give her that assistance.

talk.start.para: —I address my question to the Minister for Social Security. I remind the Minister of a report prepared and published about 12 months ago by the Australian Council of Social Service which attacked the way in which officers of the Department of Social Security treated people who applied for invalid pensions and complained about the harshness with which the 85 per cent rule was used by the Fraser Government to disqualify people from entitlement to invalid pensions. Can the Minister assure the Senate that this Government has taken steps to ensure that such a punitive approach has been abolished within the Department? Has the backlog of appeals from rejected applicants been dealt with by the appropriate tribunals?

answer.speaker: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

talk.start.para: —One of the things that have concerned this Government has been the treatment of applicants for invalid pensions. One of the problems in the past, and the problem which still remains, although I believe it is less of a problem than it was, is the divided responsibility between the Department of Social Security and the Department of Health, particularly medical officers of the Department of Health, in the assessment of invalid pension claims. I believe this has been of concern not only to ACOSS and organisations such as the Australian Council for Rehabilitation of Disabled but also to honourable senators on both sides of this House. One of the difficulties, as Senator Giles might have implied, is the definition of 'invalidity' in the social security legislation, whereby one has to prove 85 per cent disability and permanency, neither of which is very easily defined in a large number of cases. I, as a medical practitioner, find it very difficult to determine the difference between , for instance, 80 per cent disability and 90 per cent disability. At the moment we are looking at that aspect of applications as part of the handicapped programs review.

answer.para: One of the problems has always been the delay in the processing of invalid pension claims and the inconsistency of some of the application of the legislation. For instance, if one looks at the picture Australia-wide, the percentage of people who apply for and receive the invalid pension is in fact fairly consistent in the long run. However, in individual States, how people get to that position is very different. In some States in the past that position has been reached largely as part of the initial application. In other States large numbers of people have had to go through reviews and appeals, and there have been many delays. As a result of this, earlier in the year, the present Government removed the provision whereby 100 per cent of medical reviews were centralised and carried out by senior medical officers. These are now largely carried out by local medical officers at Commonwealth medical offices. The role of the central medical office is to review and maintain consistency.

The regional offices of the Department now have the primary responsibility of determining and managing invalid pension applications. As a result, the time taken to determine applications has been reduced by one-third in most cases and by more in others. We believe that the standard of initial decision making will be improved. Therefore, the number of people who will have to appeal will decrease. This will be confirmed by the continuous monitoring of the new system. I hope that at least this change will result in fewer of the delays which Senator Giles talked about. I hope that no officer of the Department of Social Security would treat invalid pension applicants in an unkind or harsh way. I believe that the vast majority of them never did. I think that the new procedures will facilitate matters and make life easier for those who have to make such determinations and as a result the whole system will be improved.

question.speaker: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

talk.start.para: —I refer the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs to the transcript of the Sunday program on which the Prime Minister appeared and to the words he uttered. He said:

question.para: . . . there is a bit of an unholy alliance temporarily between the wealthy 41-
I take it that is 41 schools--
and some sectors of the Catholic Education system-

Has the Prime Minister informed the Minister to which parts of the Catholic education system he was referring when he talked about parts of the Catholic education system being in 'an unholy alliance' in regard to the issues now before the public?

answer.speaker: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

talk.start.para: —The Prime Minister is certainly not referring to the bodies which are properly constituted for the administration of Catholic schools throughout Australia-that is the State Catholic Education Offices and the national Catholic Education Commission-because from all of these bodies we have received constructive and co-operative comment with regard to our funding decisions. However, the Prime Minister may well have been referring to those people who identify themselves as speaking for some sections of the Catholic community and who say things like their schools are worse off under our programs. Senator Baume will be aware of this, because he was present with me at a meeting last night where it was said that the category 3 schools to which most of the Catholic schools belong are worse off under our programs.

answer.para: Anybody who claims to speak for the Catholic education system and who makes a statement which is so clearly in defiance of the facts is, I believe, calling into disrepute the people he or she claims to represent and is causing many people who formerly had a very high opinion of this sector to wonder what it is all about. Whatever their capacity is, I think those people who claim to speak for some part of the Catholic education system, yet persist in gross misrepresentation of facts, are the people to whom the Prime Minister was referring. On the other hand, as I have said, the official spokesperson for Catholic education in this country, the Catholic education offices and the people from teaching orders who make such an important contribution and have made such an important contribution in the past, have made it very clear that they understand the improvements which will flow to their sector from our policies. They have said that they appreciate them and that they are especially appreciative of commitments such as the commitments to cost supplementation for wage and salary increases, the forward expenditure of capital, the special allocation of funds for new places in new schools, and so on. So there is a very widespread endorsement of a number of the essential decisions made by us, but there are some people who persist in misrepresenting the facts. I presume that it is those people to whom the Prime Minister was referring.

talk.start.para: —I ask a supplementary question. In her answer the Minister referred to a meeting at which we were present last night. I remind her that Bishop John Kelly was one of the speakers--
—Is that a supplementary question?
—If the Minister wants to avoid the issue--
—Order! I ask the honourable senator to ask the supplementary question.
—I refer the Minister to the meeting last night. Would she have included Bishop John Kelly and his fellow bishops as being among those people to whom the Prime Minister was referring?
—I do not really regard it as a supplementary question; but, as I understand it, Bishop John Kelly has no connection with the Victorian Catholic Education Office.

—I ask Senator Gietzelt, as Minister representing the Minister for Territories and Local Government, whether he is aware that many local government autorities throughout Australia are currently responsible for major innovative developments in regard to social welfare, urban planning, building design, information systems, traffic management and community arts policies. In view of the increased cost of service delivery at the local government level, can the Minister indicate what steps the government is considering taking in order to support and encourage such welcome initiatives at the local council level?

answer.speaker: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

talk.start.para: —I think the fact that the Government has appointed, for the first time as far as I am aware, a Minister for Territories and Local Government , the holder of that post being the Hon. Tom Uren, is in itself an innovative initiative in which the Government recognises the important part that local government plays in the trinity of government in Australia. It is true that local government has come a long way from its formative years, when it was largely a roads, footpaths and drainage sort of organisation. In the post war years, in particular, it has assumed a whole range of new functions, such as those to which the honourable senator has referred. The Government is greatly heartened by the initiatives that have been taken and the imaginative approach that has been shown by many local government bodies in the areas of not only administration but also service delivery, to which she has referred. The Government is very anxious actively to encourage and promote this process because citizens and ratepayers generally profit from such innovation, in terms of improved quality of life and better value for their financial investment in local government itself.

answer.para: So, as a start, I am advised that the Minister for Territories and Local Government will be introducing in the Parliament next year proposals to encompass a national award for innovation in local government. The actual, final form of the award, its value and the eligibility criteria, are still matters for determination but the Commonwealth Government is anxious to establish in the minds of local government the need to be innovative and imaginative in developing new forms of urban planning, social welfare and the whole range of community services which the people of Australia, I think, expect to be provided . In addition, the Minister for Territories and Local Government will act in liaison with the Minister for Science and Technology, Mr Barry Jones, to determine how best his department and local government generally can contribute to the Government's overall commitment to the encouragement of research and innovation and the development of new and viable industries and activities in Australia. We do believe that at that level, with its closeness to the grass roots and to communities, local government has an important part to play and the Commonwealth intends to do everything possible to encouage such innovation.

talk.start.para: —I ask the Minister representing the Treasurer whether he can inform the House and people of Australia what emblem or figurehead will be imprinted on the face of the new Australian dollar coin to be distributed in early 1984. In view of this Government's unnecessary meddling with tradition- namely, the discarding of the Victoria Cross, the abolition of the Queen's Medal , the phasing out of an allegiance to the Queen and a new design for the Australian Flag-how far removed will that emblem be from the traditional familiar ties with the monarchy?

—I am afraid that I cannot answer the specific question as to the emblem which will appear on the new $1 coin. I will ask the Treasurer and provide an answer as soon as possible. As to the other extraneous hotchpotch of matters raised by Senator Bjelke-Petersen in regard to what she termed meddling with tradition, I would just observe for the record that I understand that Senator Martin is involved in the group which is submitting designs for a new Australian flag. It seems as if the squabble in State politics in Queensland between the Country Party or the National Party, as it calls itself these days, and the Liberal Party is now being projected into the Federal Parliament.

—I ask the Minister representing the Treasurer whether he has any information indicating the accuracy or otherwise at this stage of the 1983 Budget projections. I also ask the Minister whether he can say how the accuracy of these projections compares with the economic forecasts and the accuracy thereof of the previous Liberal-National Party Government.
—Like the accuracy of Rundle share predictions in this place.

answer.speaker: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

talk.start.para: —As my colleague Senator Grimes reminds me, no government has ever produced a Budget which has been completely accurate in all its estimates of either expenditure or revenue, but I can give an unqualified guarantee that the projections of both revenue and expenditure produced by this Government in the 1983 Budget will be immeasurably more accurate than the projections of the production of oil from the Rundle project that Senator Sir John Carrick repeatedly gave to the Senate as recently as two or 2 1/2 years ago.

answer.para: I do not have any definitive figures from the Minister for Finance. I do, however, have in broad terms some information on the projections and how accurate, on present indications, they are likely to be. I understand that there could be a significant increase in the estimate of interest paid on public debt, partly attributable, or probably almost entirely attributable, to the fact that the Government's early loan raisings in funding its deficit earlier in the year were so successful. Therefore, interest on that newly acquired debt would have to be paid for a longer period than had possibly been anticipated at the time the Budget was framed.

Offsetting that, unless there is a very rapid change in present trends, will be a substantial reduction in actual payments to unemployment beneficiaries as against those which were estimated at the time the Budget was framed. I am not sure what the most recent figures are, but a couple of weeks ago the number of people actually receiving unemployment benefit had fallen by some 40,000 compared with the number at the end of the last financial year. That is a decline in unemployment benefit recipients of close to 10 per cent. As I said, unless that trend is drastically and very quickly reversed, on the expenditure side there will be a substantial over-estimate in the payments for unemployment benefit.

In general terms, there is no reason to believe at this stage that the overall estimate of the deficit will be greatly in error. Certainly, I think one could say that there is absolutely no chance that the deficit will blow out in this financial year, as it did in the last financial year when, if I remember correctly, the original estimate was $1.576 billion or thereabouts; it finally blew out to $4 1/2 billion, a threefold increase.

Of course, some of that threefold increase in the deficit which had been estimated by the previous Government last year, was due to the recession or depression being somewhat deeper than could ever reasonably have been anticipated. Some of it, of course, was due to deliberate fiddling of the figures at the time the Budget was put together in order to minimise or fool the public into believing that the deficit was, in fact, lower than it was, because at the time the 1982 Budget, the terminal Budget of the Fraser Government and the discredited former Treasurer, was presented, it was the intention of that discredited former Government to hold an election within a couple of months, before the public realised that it had cooked the books for the 1982 Budget.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism. Will the Government support the application by the Australian Paraplegic and Quadriplegic Sports Federation to hold the 1988 Olympic Games for the Disabled in Canberra? If no decision has yet been reached by the Government and with the determination of the venue to be made in Austria on 21 January 1984, will the Government announce its decision before the House rises this year?

—My colleague Mr Brown, the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, advises me that this is principally a matter for the Minister for Territories and Local Government, as the proposal by the Australian Paraplegic and Quadriplegic Sports Federation involves the staging of the Games in Canberra . The application currently rests with Mr Uren. However, Mr Brown advises me that the Government is keen to promote opportunities for disabled people to compete in international competitions and to assist with the staging of such competitions in Australia. The Government appreciates the need for the Australian delegates to be fully informed on the level of Government support for the 1988 Olympic Games for the Disabled prior to the January meeting of the International Co-ordinating Committee in Austria. The question of the level of the Government's support for the Games is presently under consideration, and a decision is expected soon. I presume that that will be before the end of this sitting of the Parliament. This is the first time that it has been drawn to my attention that there is a proposal to hold the Olympics for the Disabled in Canberra. Speaking as a senator for the Australian Capital Territory, I have to say that I would be delighted if such an event were to occur in my electorate, and I shall make sure that I add my voice to that of the Federation and support its submission.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs. Since much has been said about the supposed uncertainty of the Government's new funding formula for non-government schools, will the Minister confirm that the old percentage link did not provide the certainty and stability that its proponents now claim for it?

answer.speaker: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

talk.start.para: —One of the rather surprising things about the terms in which the current education funding debate is being conducted is the myth that has been built up around a particular way of distributing funds, which was, by giving a percentage of average government school costs to all schools in the non- government sector, the same percentage was given to all levels of category, whatever their needs, so that if the average government school costs rose by 2 per cent, a 2 per cent increase was given across the board to the non-government sector. Why such a formula, which was a very rigid one and not a very predictable one, has been turned into some sort of myth from which any departure should cause fear and trembling in the non-government sector, is something I find it very difficult to understand.
—Because it was a guarantee.

—Let us see what it was a guarantee of. It was a guarantee only that a certain measured percentage would be passed on. It was not a guarantee of an amount of money or an amount of growth. There are a number of things that should be considered by people who are now clinging to this concept of the percentage link as the best way of getting a fair deal. The elements which were put into average government school costs from which the percentage was derived, were subject to decisions of government. There was nothing totally objective and predictable about them. That is, what was counted or discounted for the purposes of this formula was very much a matter for the judgment of governments and their officials. In the case of most States, the elements in the formula were not matters of public information, and the increases provided by the percentage link formula varied quite dramatically and could not be predicted. For example, since 1980 they have ranged from almost 6 per cent in one year to less than one per cent in another year. So really, loooking at it objectively, there could be little confidence or certainty about such swings.

answer.para: One of the things that we will do is to provide a formula of funding which will give a much higher degree of predictability than what I have now described and exposed to the Senate as having been a very unreliable way of predicting costs. The Government has already improved on this unpredictable situation with which non-government schools were faced under the previous formula. In a major step, and one which still has not been widely recognised, the Government will provide retrospective cost supplementation for all grants to non-government schools from the beginning of 1984. We have backdated this recently to cover the 4.3 per cent national wage case decision of October 1983. Now this will mean the expenditures of an extra $5.8m over and above the budgetary allocation that was announced in July. An extra $5.8m has now been appropriated for non-government schools this year, in 1983, including extra funds for all schools in group 1 and group 2 categories. So there is already through this commitment to supplementation for wage and salary increases a much greater predictability than has prevailed before. I think it is time that that was acknowledged. I point out also that those schools that are now informing the parents that there will be cost increases, ought not to pretend that wage and salary increases are the cause of those fee increases because, as I have now clearly explained again to the Senate , wage and salary cost increases will be supplemented by us, and have been for the recent 4.3 per cent national wage increase.

Another point ought to be made. There has been a consistent downward trend since 1980 in the rate of increase in average government school costs. If this trend were to continue it is not inconceivable that under the old percentage link formula, the one we are hearing so much about, the per capita grants to all non-government schools might actually have declined. It is time for all of those who are seriously concerned about equity in non-government school funding to look at what the old formula really meant, how it was made up and what kind of increases passed on to non-government schools as a result of it. They will conclude, as we concluded, that it was an unsatisfactory formula, that it did not contain predictability in terms of growth and increased funds and that it certainly did nothing to do what we are determined to do, that is, to redistribute funds in terms of equity and need.

talk.start.para: —I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the President's Gallery of Mr H. M. Lodhia, MP, Chairman of the Fijian Parliament's Public Accounts Committee. On behalf of all honourable senators, I extend to Mr Lodhia a warm welcome to the Senate and I trust that his visit to Australia will be both pleasant and rewarding.

—My question, which is directed to the Attorney-General, is in two parts. Can the Attorney say how many other times he has had cause to change in a substantial fashion the Hansard record of his speeches in the time he has been in Parliament? Secondly, is it a fact that the distribution of Hansard pinks to honourable senators is for honourable senators to ascertain the correct record of their speeches and for Hansard to correct their English, where necessary, not to alter the meaning or interpretation of their speeches?

—I cannot say how many times I have added words, substracted words, rearranged words or fixed up punctuation. It has happened from time to time, as I gather would be the case for every honourable senator in this place. I challenge any other senator who has not ever added a word to any pink that has been put in front of him to rise in his place, wave his hand about, waggle his fingers or do something.
—His or her.

—Yes. The reality of the matter is that that is the way we carry on in this place, provided that in doing so we do not alter the sense, the text or the substance of what we produce. If I am behaving with an insufferable sense of righteousness in this matter, it is because I have an insufferable sense of the rectitude of my behaviour on this particular occasion.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. The Minister did not answer two parts of my question. What I asked was how many other times has he had cause in a substantial fashion to alter his speeches. He has referred to punctuation and things like that. I also asked him: 'Is a fact that the distribution of Hansard pinks to honourable senators is for honourable senators to ascertain the correct record of their speeches and for Hansard to correct their English, where necessary, not to alter the meaning or interpretation of their speeches'.
—I have nothing useful or in any other way to add to my previous answer.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a report in the Australian of today's date that a future Liberal-National Party government would sell public sector businesses to private interests, tighten up the Public Service and increase the number of expert ministerial staff? This announcement was made by Jim Carlton, MHR, former Health Minister in the Fraser Government. Will the Minister inform the Senate which government-owned businesses are likely to be affected by any proposals put forward by Mr Carlton for the Opposition? Finally, in which area are these services likely to be cut and what cuts are likely to be made in the Public Service?

answer.speaker: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

talk.start.para: —The final part of Senator Jones's question was: Which government businesses are likely to be affected by the Opposition's policy? I think the answer to that question is none because the Opposition is unlikely to be in a position to implement its policies, whatever they may be, for a very considerable time. Unless the Opposition gets its game together more than it has been able to do either today or on any previous occasion in the Senate or the House of Representatives, I would say it is unlikely ever to be able to implement its policies. The policies it has put forward are really not terribly relevant to the future of, say for example, Trans Australia Airlines, Telecom Australia, the Australian National Railways Commission or Australia Post. However, there remains, I suppose, always hope and always the possibility that the Opposition will improve its performance and behave a bit more responsibly than it has so far in opposition and perhaps, at some time, may be in a position again where it may win an election and actually form a government.

answer.para: What would be the result if these policies announced by Mr Carlton were actually to be taken seriously? I do not intend to canvass the matter in great detail, but one of the objectives of a previous Liberal-National Party government was to sell off the profitable portions of Telecom. If that is done by a future Liberal-National Party government, if there is going to be one, there is little doubt-indeed, I would say there is no doubt-that certain sections of the Telecom enterprise would be readily purchased by the private sector and those sections would be quite profitable. The consequences of that, of course, are that charges currently levelled by Telecom for the services it provides in areas which are not profitable would have to be substantially increased or the services withdrawn or reduced. That is a matter which ought to be of particular concern to the National Party senators from Queensland who claim to have a particular interest in people who live outside the capital cities. In Queensland, of course, a higher proportion of the population lives outside the capital city than in any other mainland State. The effect of this ' Liberal-National Party policy', should the Liberal-National Party ever return to power and sell off the profitable sections of Telecom, would be either to increase drastically the cost or to reduce drastically the quality of the service provided by Telecom in most, if not all, of Queensland outside the Brisbane metropolitan area and, of course, in many other parts of Australia. That is a matter to which I would have thought that one of the senators who purports to represent Queensland, to wit, Senator Bjelke-Petersen, would be well advised to turn her mind rather than asking the sort of question that she asked earlier today.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Attorney-General. I refer to the statement which the Attorney-General put out last Friday when he sought to explain his use of certain words in the Senate which included the suggestion that I had deliberately twisted his words and taken the words out of context. Why did he not give the full context of the question in that he referred only to the first part of Senator Sir John Carrick's question and not to the part which related to the possible resignation of the Foreign Minister? Why did he specifically quote his own words within quotation marks without explaining the change which he had made to that quotation?
—Tell him.
—There is a variety of things I am tempted to tell him, Senator, but I am only being asked with relation to a couple of them.
—Order! I ask the Attorney-General to answer through the Chair.
—He gets into trouble when he gets miffed.
—I am sorry, but the questions are so trivial that I think I have already forgotten what they were. The first question was: Why did I what? I am sorry; can I have some assistance, Mr President?
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition might ask his question again.

—Mr President, I am happy to repeat the question for the Attorney . He might listen this time. I refer to the statement which Senator Evans went to the trouble to put out on Friday afternoon in an attempt to explain the words he had used in Question Time that day. He suggested in that that his words had been twisted and taken out of context. He then went on supposedly to provide the context but omitted reference to the fact that the question also referred to whether Mr Hayden should consider resignation. So that was part of the context of the question. He also went on, to quote his own words, without explaining that he had added a word to what he had quoted and it was not in fact what he had said in the Senate. I ask him why he omitted the full context of the question, since he was trying to clear up what he said was twisting, and why he omitted to explain that he had added words.

answer.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: —It is still a very odd question.
—Why don't you go away and think about it?

—The trouble is that I do not have the statement with me. The answer that I gave was specifically directed to the context of the general application of that principle. That was the context in which I gave my answer. It was from that context that Senator Chaney wrenched a particular sentence and chose to apply it to the particular context of Mr Hayden.

answer.para: I chose not to answer the original question I was asked in any context other than a general context. When I was pressed in a supplementary question for not having answered the particular question I was asked, and therein lies the answer to Senator Chaney's question, Senator Sir John Carrick got to his feet and said: 'Why haven't you answered my specific question? I was not asking about the general principle, I was asking about this particular Minister'. I refused to add anything to what I had previously said. The course of events speaks for itself.

talk.start.para: —You just misquoted a supplementary question.

—This is very tiresome. As to why I did not put in inverted commas the word 'always', I have answered that sufficiently today with the proposition that I saw it as doing no more than clarifying the meaning of a sentence which was already clear by virtue of the context in which it sat and it did not in any way change the meaning, substance, effect or anything else about it. If Senator Chaney wants to waste any further time on this, I will be happy to accommodate him, but I suggest that it is not getting either of us anywhere.

question.speaker: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

talk.start.para: —At Question Time last Friday Senator Foreman asked me a question about payments under the community employment program in the State of South Australia. I have now obtained an answer for him, which is that in South Australia, as at 4 November, a total of 40 projects involving 408 jobs had been approved under the CEP. Under the State component of the community employment program, 13 projects had been approved as at 4 November 1983. These projects will result in the creation of 143 jobs. The level of projects approvals represents 20 per cent of the total CEP project approvals nationally.

question.para: The number of jobs in South Australia-143 in these approved projects-is higher than in any other State to date, the next highest being New South Wales with 108 jobs in approved projects. Under the Commonwealth component of the community employment program, 27 projects have been approved in South Australia involving the creation of 265 jobs. In the case of the Commonwealth CEP, the number of projects approved in South Australia to date represents 14 per cent of the total number of projects approved nationally and the number of jobs in these projects represents 10 per cent of the total number of jobs in Commonwealth CEP projects approved so far.

question.speaker: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

talk.start.para: —On 30 November Senator Missen asked me a question relating to the Arab League boycott of Israel. I undertook to supply an answer to him, which is as follows: The Australian Government has never been advised officially of the Arab boycott of Israel. The Government is aware, however, of its existence and the fact that it has been applied in varying degrees of intensity for some 20 years. The Australian Government does not endorse the Arab boycott of Israel. The Department of Trade has an obligation to ensure, however, that Australian exporters are fully informed of the import requirements of overseas markets. Indeed, the Department would be failing in its duty if it did not inform exporters of the requirements of importing countries affecting Australian exporters' access to the markets concerned, irrespective of whether those requirements concerned matters such as the boycott.

question.para: In relation to the comments in the specific article in question, the Minister for Trade understands that, although he was not aware of it at the time, in the context of discussions relating to Australian participation in the Baghdad International Trade Fair, certain material was furnished by the Perth office of the Department of Trade relating to the Arab boycott. However, in August the Minister had drawn to his attention that the Melbourne regional office of the Department was disseminating information relating to the boycott, which had been interpreted by some to suggest that the Australian Government was not opposed to the boycott. After considering the matter the Minister took the position that information relating to the boycott must necessarily be given to Australian exporters, but when it is distributed it must be made clear that the Australian Government does not endorse the Arab boycott and that the information supplied in no way represents or reflects Australian Government policy. His Department issued an instruction to that effect to all its regional officers on 16 September. In the view of the Minister the Department would be failing in its duty if it withheld any information on matters affecting Australian exporters' access to overseas markets.

question.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: —On 15 November Senator Chipp asked a question concerning Soviet nuclear doctrine in relation to the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation intermediate-range nuclear force modernisation program. The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided an answer, which I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard.

question.para: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-

speech.speaker: Mason Sen C.V.J.

talk.start.para: —I wish to raise some of the matters concerning the future of the people of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands. It is a fact , of course, that following a United Nations decolonisation investigation a referendum is to be held among the people so that they can decide on their future. I am speaking on this matter now because I am afraid that various pressures will be put on the people of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands, who are essentially Malay people, to vote for integration with Australia. If this were to happen, they would become a tiny minority of the Canberra electorate of Fraser and in no way could their vote on any issue be relevant. This would not be giving those people self government. I remind honourable senators, through you, Mr Deputy President, that these people are Australian citizens; we have taken on a responsibility for them.

speech.para: The United Nations mission did suggest as one possible option that a proposal be put in the referendum whereby the people could vote for some form of free association with virtually any country. I think the implication there was that that free association could well be with Australia. One would assume that it would be agreed that matters like foreign affairs, defence and possibly a basic oversight of the economy of the islands would be carried out by Australia, but that there would be some attempt to preserve local autonomy in local affairs. It is a fact that the people of the Cocos Islands, like most Malay people, use a consensus system of government amongst themselves, which is very highly developed, and they are very well equipped to decide their own affairs in a peaceful and constructive way. They understand their ideas and the way in which they want their affairs to be carried out in the future. I think-and I think other honourable senators might care to think about this-that a virtual dictatorship of Canberra officials on these islands over those people would be a disaster of the first magnitude. We are kidding ourselves if we believe that by integration and by making them voters in Fraser we are giving them any sort of political power. I think that is absolute nonsense. It would also prove to be outrageously expensive. Through you, Mr Deputy President, I would like to commend to honourable senators a look at page 35 of the report that we are now considering. They will find that in 1981-82 the islands had a revenue of some $ 811,000, mostly from sales of copra, which does not sell all that well these days, and an expenditure of almost $6m. Hence, it is costing Australian taxpayers $5m a year, or some $10,000 a year in subsidy for every one of the men , women and children, 546 of them, living on these islands. Of those, 319 are Malays.

On this basis, I wonder whether the Government would at this stage consider letting a small expert committee of some kind, which understands these people, or alternatively a committee of one House or the other of the Parliament, which I understand can take evidence from people, look at the matter. We have it in our power now to destroy completely, and I mean completely, the tradition and way of life of a significant group of people at great expense to ourselves, or not to do so.

I would also like to call into question the Government's extraordinary decision to throw Mr John Clunies-Ross and his family out of the house and property they have occupied for over a century. There are only, I believe, some five hectares of land involved. This decision was conveyed to Mr Clunies-Ross, as has been publicised, in a letter of 19 July of this year from Mr Tom Uren, the Minister for Territories and Local Government, who wrote:
. . . the Commonwealth wishes to purchase all your remaining real property interests in the Cocos (Keeling) Islands.
He offers valuation and then adds:
It is the Government's intention that, should you decline to sell these interests to the Commonwealth, consideration will be given to using the compulsory powers of the Lands Acquisition Act 1955.

I should inform you that following the acquisition of your real property interests the Commonwealth will seek vacant possession as soon as possible and, in this respect, the Commonwealth intends that you then leave and remain away from the Cocos (Keeling) Islands.

I find this quite extraordinary. It seems to be a gross intrusion on individual rights and seems to usher in a phase of Australian colonialist autocracy, orchestrated I might say by the Australian Labor Party, probably unparalleled by the empires and rajahs of the 19th century. It is the sort of autocratic action that has no justification whatsoever. I wondered whether the justification might have been that Mr John Clunies-Ross was highly unpopular in the islands. The Committee on Science and the Environment, of which I am a member, spent a little time on the Cocos (Keeling) Islands earlier this year and I made inquiries, as best I could, among a number of people. It seems that Mr John Clunies-Ross is not regarded as a particular menace. He has no political power there. People still come to see him and take his advice on matters. He has a sort of vaguely paternal role towards those people. He regards that place as his only home. The proposal is that he should be thrown out of it. Of course, this is in direct contravention of the Commonwealth's final agreement with him under which he sold the bulk of the islands, including its plantations, in 1978. That final agreement to sell was conditional upon the Government's agreeing to his retaining the family homestead.
