In terms of the convention market the Government believes that a convention centre such as is proposed will mean that Australians will no longer be required to travel out of the country because of a lack of facilities here. That can only benefit all sectors of the Australian community. Also, to date Canberra has been sorely lacking in suitable venues for entertainment. The Government also recognises that, around the world, convention centres, in and of themselves, are not economically viable. Other governments, as we know from the empirical evidence, have had to offer a range of concessions to ensure that such important facilities are provided. If we are to have private investment in this type of project there must naturally be the prospect of an economic return; otherwise the funds will not be provided. The inclusion of the casino as a part of the complex will enable the development to take place without the need for a substantial government subsidy.

Honourable senators will be aware that when the House of Assembly considered the proposed amendment last week it recommended to the Minister for Territories and Local Government that the proposal that was rejected by the previous Government should stand-without a casino as part of the complex. The House of Assembly was almost evenly divided on the question. The vote on the proposal was as close as it could be-10 votes to eight. The decision taken was contrary to the two decisions taken on previous occasions when the House of Assembly has discussed the matter. In 1979 and in 1981 the House of Assembly supported, by a substantial majority, a casino proposal. So it must be borne in mind that the Assembly, in making its decision would not have been responsible for providing the concessions. That would be a Commonwealth contribution. The Assembly was not faced with a hard-nosed financial decision, but rather with advice based upon this Government bearing and wearing the consequences. Indeed, the report of the House of Assembly Select Committee which inquired into the casino proposal could not readily come up with any substantial or valid reason for opposing it. Notwithstanding its wide-ranging inquiry, it could find no evidence which would support a recommendation against the proposal on rational grounds.

Let me turn briefly to one of the matters raised by Senator Chipp. He said that because of a number of factors, including the closeness of the Assembly vote, we should hold a referendum on the issue; that such a referendum should be held on 25 February next, when the Government is to take five constitutional proposals to the Australian people. I wish to make clear the Government's position on this matter. It is the same as was put to Senator Chipp by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in his letter last month. The Prime Minister said that he thought it would be inappropriate to have a referendum on this matter. The Government wishes on 25 February to gain the support of the people of Australia on five important constitutional proposals, proposals which have been debated in the Senate and supported. Therefore, it would be an inappropriate time to have the people of Canberra distracted from these very important matters by having to consider a local issue. As the Prime Minister said in his letter, governments are elected to govern and referendums should be held only on matters of great importance or in cases where it was necessary because of constitutional obligations. That is the position that the Government has taken. We do not feel that it is appropriate further to delay the proposition by waiting until February in order to conduct a referendum. The need for office space in Canberra is far too urgent an issue to permit waiting on the outcome of a local vote. The Government has brought forth a development package designed to ease that accommodation shortage quickly. Senator Reid herself is aware of the difficulties that my Department has had in finding suitable accommodation. Many government departments and areas of the private sector are greatly concerned about the lack of such accommodation in Canberra. The Government considered the referendum question when it first looked at the matters which led to today's debate. It then rejected that option and it still rejects it. I ask honourable senators, therefore, to consider the provisions of the Ordinance, first, as a set of controls for a discreet casino in the Australian Capital Territory; secondly, as allowing for the development of a total complex which will benefit the community; thirdly, as lessening the drain on Commonwealth revenue; and, fourthly, as providing a much needed boost to Canberra's economy.

Let us look at the Ordinance on its merits. It provides the tightest possible control and sets a standard for the rest of the nation in this field. I therefore ask honourable senators not to make a cheap political decision today but rather to look at the Ordinance as a positive action, one taken in good faith and with the best of intentions. Honourable senators should remind themselves of the context in which the Government took this decision. It is not a simple matter. It is not just a matter of building a casino, allegedly to spoil the Canberra scene. It is providing for the nation's capital a much needed complex and I urge all honourable senators, particularly those from States where casinos are operating, or will be operating as a result of State Government interest in the matter, to reject Senator Reid's motion and the cynical politics that I believe it represents.

speech.speaker: Reid Sen M.E.

talk.start.para: —in reply-I wish to deal with a number of matters that have been raised by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) in his speech this afternoon. About half of it can be used to support, and does support, the argument that I gave initially: That we do need a convention centre in Canberra; that we do need office space in Canberra; that we do need the development that White Industries is prepared to go ahead with and for which it has $130m available, to provide for the jobs that would flow from it. I call upon the Government again to proceed with that proposal forthwith. There is no requirement whatever to hold a referendum on that. There is no reason whatever to deprive this community of the benefits that it would gain from such a convention centre, international hotel and office complex, on the basis previously agreed upon.

speech.para: The Minister referred to the need for an increase in tourism. I wish we could take him seriously, but in the Budget that was put down in August, there was no evidence whatever of support for increased tourist promotion for the Australian Capital Territory. For the promotion of tourism the provision of the Budget this year was $500,000, exactly the same amount as was provided last year, which, in real terms, represents a decrease in expenditure on that area of activity. In contrast, most other States have increased their budget for tourist promotion this year by about 68 per cent.

The Minister has referred to the need for a diversified economic base. I could not agree more, and the hotel-convention centre that had been agreed upon would assist in providing that base. The real tragedy of the decision that the Government is attempting to inflict upon this community is the way in which White Industries has been treated. That, of course, if the Government does not go ahead with the proposal, will be something from which this community will probably suffer for a very long period. The Minister called upon senators to say that the Australian Capital Territory should have these benefits-a convention centre-international hotel complex. Of course we need these things and we can have them because we know they are available. It has been suggested that the incentives needed to get them are too high. What about the position in New South Wales? What about the booklet 'Assistance for development in New South Wales, Australia', a document comprising some 39 pages that has been put out by the New South Wales Department of Industrial Development and Decentralisation? Why do we not engage in a little bit of pro Australian Capital Territory activity, instead of knocking it all the time? How about going ahead with the proposals that were put forward and which were acceptable to this community? If the Prime Minister ( Mr Hawke) still wants a casino, he can pursue that as a separate matter. No reason has been given for abandoning this project, just because somebody wants a casino. What real jobs would flow from having a casino in this complex? The number of construction jobs which would be available in the building of a complex with a casino would be the same as for a complex without a casino. The Prime Minister, in answering a question as to additional jobs, provided the only evidence relating to the provision of additional jobs; those jobs were for young girls in the casino. That is not something about which everybody in this community is pleased.

We should consider the other implications of jobs. Mr Dawkins, the Minister for Finance, has made no financial statement regarding this Ordinance, although he promised to make such statements with respect to Bills. I appreciate that the ordinance is not a Bill, a matter I will come back to. We have had no financial statement setting out the benefits to this community from this project, from a financial point of view. We have had no statement about consultation with the community. A report, prepared by Mr Peter Bennett, entitled 'An Assessment of the Impact of Poker Machine Gambling on the Victorian Gambling Market' covers a number of quite interesting matters. It gives the details of expenditure on poker machine gambling in the Australian Capital Territory at present, namely $ 13.842m. I wonder how many more dollars are available in this community for gambling and whether, in fact, gambling in a casino, discreet or otherwise, would be done with money taken from poker machine gambling. At the conclusion of this quite lengthy report, Mr Bennett makes it very plain in referring to the impact of additional gambling outlets in Tasmania and Victoria that the impact on horse racing would be quite severe. He dealt with the effect on gallop races in more detail than that on harness races or on greyhound races. He concluded that there are risks to the racing industry.

The number of people employed in Canberra in the racing industry at present is about 604. I wonder how many of those, on the evidence that is available about the shift in the gambling dollar from one place to another, would lose their jobs. We have seen no information from the Government which would give us any confidence whatever in the continued employment of the 604 persons presently employed in the Canberra- Queanbeyan area in the thoroughbred racing industry; nor have we received information to indicate that additional jobs would be provided in the casino. I wonder whether the number of jobs would really be different. In Atlantic City, six casinos over a period were set up. The effect was to force three thoroughbred racing operations to close. They were forced out of business with the advent of the casinos. It might be said that gambling exists and that there is no real difference between the forms of gambling, but I think the evidence is there to show that the jobs are really only being shifted from one gambling industry to another.

We come back to the question of why there is such determination to have a casino and what real benefit would flow to the community. We were promised by the honourable member for Canberra during the election campaign that the White Industries hotel-convention centre proposal would go ahead without the requirement for a casino. Why is it that that promise has been dumped and we are forced into this situation? There was an attack made by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs on the previous Minister for the Capital Territory concerning the fact that this decision was made near the end of the term of the previous Government. I remind the Minister that in 1976 the then Minister for the Capital Territory did not overturn a recently made decision of the previous Minister for the Capital Territory to take away from the Trades and Labour Council block 4, section 13 of Civic which had been given to it in the dying stages of the previous Government. The Minister for the Capital Territory who then took over was not impressed with what he found on this matter. He would have liked to overturn the decision, but he felt obliged to honour the commitment made to the Trades and Labour Council and he did so. The lease was granted as late as 30 June 1977. It commenced from 13 March 1976. I think the dates speak for themselves as to the Liberal Government's honouring of a commitment which had been made by a Labor Government. So I am not very impressed with that argument for abandoning this proposal.

We have heard of the previous decisions of the House of Assembly. I think the Minister would have to agree that a number of royal commission reports and reports of other inquiries have been published since the House of Assembly made those decisions. It did not have the benefit of having the documents which it now has. I do not know about the Minister at the table, but as far as I am concerned if I could win every issue by 10 votes to eight votes, I would be quite happy. The reality is that the vote was really higher on this occasion. The Labor leader of the House of Assembly, Maureen Horder, put out a Press release on 22 September 1983 in which she said:
The ALP view-not to support any proposal for the construction of a Casino-was established on Sunday--
that is, 21 November-
and at no subsequent stage was this position changed. The ALP did not vote for a Casino.

So six of the eight votes were not in favour of a casino. That adds up to me to a vote of 16 to two for this community not wanting or needing a casino. It has been suggested that nothing has been put forward that is improper, immoral or wrong in respect of casinos in the other States. The main argument in this debate, as far as I am concerned, is the harm done to this community by the attack of this Government on the White Industries proposal. A private developer who has put forward a proposal on which he has spent a lot of money and on which he has the money to continue spending has been told to go away and that the project is not really wanted. That will make it very hard indeed for us again to attract private money to Canberra.

I turn to the legislation. We have heard about what model legislation it is. Certainly, the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances did not criticise it. But there are aspects of the legislation that I think the Senate should look at before it contemplates passing or allowing this Ordinance to become law. Section 21 of the Australian Capital Territory Ordinance makes provision for the assignment of a casino ordinance with the approval of the Minister, but the Ordinance is totally silent on the issue of mortgaging, charging or otherwise encumbering the casino licence. In fact, financial deals could go on behind closed doors which would have nothing to do with changing the name of the licensee, which the Minister would have to approve. We may have no idea at all whose money is behind the casino, whose money controls it and who really calls the shots as to what is done there. I think it is a very serious defect in the legislation that there is no prohibition on any form of encumbrance on the licence that the Minister would have to approve. Section 57 of the Ordinance provides that a person shall not be employed to perform duties relating to gaming in the casino unless that person is the holder of a casino employee's licence, and the licence may be granted by the Minister. But the Ordinance is totally silent on what criteria should be taken into account when determining whether a licence should be granted to an employee. Those are just two matters. There are other defects, I suggest, with regard to internal controls, administrative, accounting and auditing requirements. These defects would be serious indeed if this project were to go ahead.

I will briefly review some of the issues. The reason given by the Minister for Territories and Local Government (Mr Uren) for why there could not be a referendum was that it would cause division within the Labor Party. That is some way to run a country, I must say! The legislation which we have before us is an Ordinance which we cannot amend under the Seat of Government Act. Thus, we could not do very much about the defects to which I have just referred. If a Bill, a Commonwealth statute, had been brought in, amendments could have been made to it which would have made the legislation, if it were to become law, more acceptable .

The Ordinance was not first referred to the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly, in spite of the Government's promise and commitment that legislation would be so referred. It is very interesting that the two Ordinances which did not get to the House of Assembly until after they had been gazetted and tabled are the two Ordinances with which we are dealing today and tomorrow. Some explanation ought to be given as to why that is so, associated with what I referred to previously-the indecent haste with which this legislation was brought into being.

There need be no further delay in getting the important project that the Minister has outlined in detail under way in the Australian Capital Territory. From March until now we have waited for the jobs that could already have been available on the project that was approved. As I have said previously, I ask the Government to go ahead forthwith. The incentives are not excessive. They are incentives that are reasonable to be given to enable the hotel-convention centre to get under way and the office block to be built to provide the office accommodation that is very much needed at present. Enough harm has been done to the private sector in Canberra by the actions of this Government. Enough jobs have already been delayed or lost as a result of this. I ask the Senate to support the motion for disallowance, and I ask the Government to go ahead with the approved proposal forthwith.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Reid's) be agreed to.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

proctext.para: Debate resumed from 11 May 1983, on motion by Senator Button:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

speech.speaker: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

talk.start.para: —The Referendum (Constitution Alteration) Amendment Bill 1983 was introduced in the Senate a considerable time ago. For some reason that is not clear to me, it has been brought on for debate only towards the end of this session. There seems to be no explanation as to why the matter was not dealt with in May, when it was introduced, I think, or at least earlier this session. It is an important Bill because it seeks to give the residents of the Territories a right to vote in a referendum to alter the Constitution. That is its purpose. The Senate will recall that the Constitution was altered after a referendum in 1977, to give, among other things, the residents of the Territories the right to vote at referendums. This Bill provides the necessary statutory machinery to enable them to do so. Therefore, it is an important Bill. The Opposition supports it, as indeed, when in government, we promoted the referendum in 1977 which altered the Constitution to enable them to exercise that right. However, as I have said, legislation was necessary to give the full effect to it. Although the Opposition is not opposed in any way to the Bill, it is concerned about some other aspects of the Referendum (Constitution Alteration) Act and proposes in this debate to take the opportunity of moving amendments which relate to the concerns we have about these other aspects.

speech.para: First and foremost, we are very concerned indeed by the decision of the Government to spend $1 1/4m of taxpayers' moneys, public money, in promoting the Yes case in the referendums on the five topics that will be put to the people at the end of February. The Opposition believes this is a totally unwarranted form of expenditure, and the promotion of the referendums should be one for the parties concerned to support or to oppose, for the people to support or oppose as they form their views, and as with any other election campagin, the expenses should be met by the people concerned.

We have already had very considerable debate in the Parliament recently about public funding. The Opposition made its views very fimly and very clearly in opposition to the proposal for public funding. Yet here we have the Government, without any legislative authority to do so, providing public funds to promote its referendum proposals. The fact that the Opposition has said it supports the proposals and that the Australian Democrats support them is absolutely no justification in our opinion for public funds to be used in the campaign. As I have said, we are against public funds being used in election campaigns and against public funds being used in a referendum campaign other than, of course, the necessary funding which is part and parcel of a referendum or an election.

The Referendum (Constitution Alteration) Act already provides for funding of the Yes and No cases. That is very even handed. It stipulates who can write the Yes and No cases and provides for those cases to be distributed by the Chief Electoral Officer. The whole process is one of informing the electors on both sides of the referendum proposals.That is not what the Government is proposing here. In addition to that provision in the Referendum (Constitution Alteration) Act, the Government proposes to spend $1 1/4, not to be divided equally and, indeed, not giving any proportion of it to those who wish to promote the No case . The whole of this money is being used by the Government to promote the Yes case. Obviously, it is a promotion on a large scale and in addition to the distribution of the Yes and No cases. The Opposition expected that at the very least the Government would provide some funds for those promoting the No case; but not a bit of it is so provided. The whole of the money is being provided for the Government's case. The Opposition will move an amendment to prevent any sums of money being used by the Commonwealth in addition to those already provided for in the Referendum (Constitution Alteration) Act in relation to the distribution of the Yes and No cases.

The other point with which the Opposition is concerned-it also relates to other provisions of the Referendum (Constitution Alteration) Act-is the form of the ballot paper which is to be used in the referendum, and in particular the question which is to be put to the electors. The Referendum (Constitution Alteration) Act makes it quite clear that the form of the question on the ballot paper is as follows:
Do you approve of the proposed law for the alteration of the Constitution entitled (here set out the title of the proposed law)?

The title of the proposed law is the long title of the Act. That has traditionally been the way in which the question is put to the electors. That is based upon the best and highest principle, namely, that the long title is the one which has been approved by the Parliament. In the passage of the legislation , which is then put to the people at the referendum, the title of the proposed law is determined by the Parliament. That is the principle that ought to apply.

However, the existing Referendum (Constitution Alteration) Act does permit the form of the ballot paper to be prescribed by regulations; in other words, the form in the Schedule may be prescribed by regulations. As we discovered recently , the regulations have been made to alter the form C or form D, as in this case because there are multiple questions. Form D deals with multiple questions, but the same issue is at stake. The regulations have made the question to provide for questions in another form rather than involving the long title of the Bill. I do not know whether those regulations have been tabled yet, but the Opposition believes that those regulations should not have been permitted to take effect and that the question should remain as it traditionally has been and as is provided for in the form of the Act to which I referred.

One option would be for the Opposition to move to disallow those regulations, but we believe that the matter should be taken further and this is obviously an opportunity of doing so. We believe that the forms which are laid down in the Act should not be subject to change by regulation. As I have said, the Parliament, when it passes a proposed law, sets out in the title of the proposed law what it believes is the right way of describing it. Parliament knows that the forms of the ballot paper as set out in the Act require the title of the proposed law to be set out in the question. Therefore, it should not be a matter of making regulation to change that.

The Opposition will move amendments to ensure that the traditional forms and the traditional question, namely, the long title of the proposed law, should not be subject to change by a government in making regulations. When all is said and done, the Government could well make regulations when Parliament was not sitting and the Parliament might not sit before the referendum was held. There might be no opportunity at all for Parliament to disallow them if it disapproves of them. As I said, we have a series of amendments to give effect to that concern. We wish to amend the Act in such a way as to prevent any government in the future changing the existing situation as a result of the actions that the Government has taken.

The Opposition will be moving some other fairly minor amendments to the Bill. However, I will deal with them when we come to the Committee stage of this debate. At this stage the Opposition fully supports the principle of the Bill. It certainly will give it a second reading and, in the Committee stage, will seek to achieve amendments which it regards as very important-not so much, as I said, amendments to the actual Bill, but amendments to the Referendum ( Constitution Alteration) Act. Our amendments relate to the two matters about which we are concerned and with which I have already dealt. I hope they will be supported by honourable senators.

speech.speaker: Macklin Sen M.J.

talk.start.para: — The Referendum (Constitution Alteration) Amendment Bill relates to a previous referendum in which the people of Australia overwhelmingly agreed that the people of the Territories in Australia ought to have the right to vote in referenda. It is a technical Bill to enable the various technical problems to be overcome for the referenda to be held on 25 February. The Opposition has indicated that it will be moving a range of amendments in the Committee stage as will the Australian Democrats. The problem has become somewhat murky now that the Government has circulated a series of amendments that it intends proposing in the Committee stage.

speech.para: I turn, first of all, to the original set of amendments that the Australian Democrats circulated to honourable senators in May when last we saw this Bill. They referred to two principal items. First of all they referred to the problems which were raised by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills in relation to the very wide powers seemingly given by the Referendum (Constitution Alteration) Act to the Chief Australian Electoral Officer to alter the ballot paper in such a way as to make it acceptable for use in the Territories. The actual wording of the Act is very broad. It seemed to us that some specification of that very broad power ought to be included in the Act. Therefore, we will be moving a range of amendments in relation to that. The Government has circulated a series of amendments in relation to the same proposition. If time permits, negotiations should proceed so that we can actually sort out whether it is necessary to move what I understand to be three separate groups of amendments to the one proposition to achieve something about which, I think, all parties in the Senate agree.

The second group of amendments that I proposed in May dealt with the ability of the ethnic community to understand, in detail, the situation in relation to the proposed referenda. It is a difficult situation. The proposition contained within the Democrats' amendments very much supported the notion that the ethnic communities ought to have available to them a range of materials in languages other than English to enable them to undertake the task. The Democrats propose that the booklet containing the Yes and No cases be printed in a range of important ethnic languages and that these be available at places such as post offices. (Quorum formed)

The Democrats propose, in the Committee stage, to move an amendment to enable the dominant ethnic communities to have printed in their own languages a technical document referring to our Constitution. I think it ought to be clearly understood that, while people may learn to speak, with a fair facility, a second language, it is sometimes difficult, in a second langauge, to comprehend fully a technical matter in a vocabulary area which is not often used in the community. Therefore, I believe that, it would be useful for the dominant ethnic communities in Australia to have available to them the Yes and No cases in their original languages. It is an anomaly that we have not yet undertaken such a course in Australia, given that it has been accepted for some time that we are a multicultural society. I hope that the Government will be able to meet the Democrats' propositions so that that may be undertaken, though not necessarily in the way we are presenting. If the Government has some propositions on this, we certainly will be very happy to look at them.

The next issue that I will raise in the Committee stage was raised by Senator Durack in his speech a moment ago. It seems to us that, up to the present, the funding of referenda has been done in an even-handed way from the Commonwealth's viewpoint. This time around, of course, we are confronted with a somewhat different problem from two viewpoints. The Premiers of Queensland and Tasmania, prior to the announcement of the Government's expenditure on the Yes case, said that they would be launching a campaign equivalent to an election campaign in favour of the No case. Presumably, that would only be able to be undertaken by the expenditure of public moneys. It seems to me that what we have, then, is an anomalous situation of some States expending public moneys on an election campaign in favour of the No case and the Government, whose response to this has been equally silly, spending federal moneys on the Yes case.

However, if one attempts to draw a principle line, it is very difficult for the Federal Parliament to predicate its actions on what a State may or may not do. So in relation to the Yes and No cases there is always the possibility that whereas the conservative governed States in Australia-Queensland, Tasmania and the Northern Territory, which will have power when this Bill is passed to engage in a referendum campaign-may spend public moneys on the No case, the State Labor governments of New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia and Western Australia may very well spend public moneys on the Yes case. So we are in a very difficult situation in relation to the expenditure of moneys at the State level. It is a pity that this is now occurring because the principle underlying the even- handedness of the campaigns mounted at the Federal level is entrenched in the Act. The Democrats believe that as far as possible this ought to be pursued in that even-handed way and therefore we have circulated amendments to that effect and will be speaking in greater detail about that matter at the Committee stage.

I believe it is important to draw attention to the other item raised by Senator Durack. The Government has circulated some amendments of its own which we have had the chance to examine in only a cursory way. We hope that before we get to the Committee stage we will be able to have a more in-depth discussion with the Government and also examine them in greater detail ourselves particularly in regard to the propositions surrounding the change of wording on the ballot paper . The Democrats accept the principle which we believe is behind the Government's move on this, that there ought to be a form of words on the ballot paper which is easily understood and comprehended by the electors-I think that is a reasonable proposition-so that they are not confronted with a rather erudite and technical proposition to vote in favour of the wording of either the long or the short title of a Bill.

talk.start.para: —What if they do not reflect the real argument?

—If the honourable senator will hold everything, I will get to the problem that he raises shortly. So the original intent, we hope, of the Government certainly meets with the approval of the Democrats. Indeed, that is what we understood from discussions we have had with the Attorney-General ( Senator Gareth Evans).

speech.para: I want to put the history of this matter clearly. It is important so that we might be able to sort out where we are going. When first approached by the Attorney on this matter the Democrats made it very clear that our position was that the wording ought to be included in the original Bill, thereby giving Parliament at the time it was considering the Bill the ability to consider also the wording which would be on the ballot paper. We believe it is appropriate in these very delicate matters for the Parliament itself to make that type of determination, not to have it made by regulation. However, we were informed by the Attorney that under the current Act sufficient power lies with the Government, by regulation, to change the ballot paper by regulation. On that understanding we said that it was quixotic on our part to hold out that it ought to be in the Act if the Attorney already had the power, and we were willing at that point to discuss wordings. It was our belief at that time that it was the Government's intention to have a discussion not only with us but also with the opposition parties so that the wording would reflect--

talk.start.para: —A consensus.

—Yes, it would reflect a consensus, as Senator Chipp reminds me, of what all parties believed was a fair and accurate depiction of what the Bills in question were about. Had that been achieved in those discussions, we may not have been at the position we are at now. But I understand, from a cursory examination of some of the amendments that the Government has circulated, that it may very well now be the case that the Government is having doubts as to whether it actually did have the power to do what it did in regard to statutory rule 274.
—It is just an abundance of draftsman's caution.

—The Attorney can enlighten us in his response to this second reading stage as to why it is we are looking at a couple of these amendments which, to my way of thinking, seem to suggest that the Government does not have the power that we were led to believe it had. So I restate the Democrat's position. Our original position still stands-we would much prefer that the Parliament, when it is debating a Bill concerning a referendum, also debate what it is that will go on the ballot paper so that we can have a clear and distinct understanding of the question that will be put to the people and that the question unambiguously reflects the content of the Bill. I believe that the regulations do so reflect the questions but the matter could have been put beyond doubt had there been discussions between the Government and the major opposition parties so that the major opposition parties could concur with the wording of those questions. That would have included those people in the opposition parties or in the Senate who opposed the referendum Bills, because I believe that the original Act does give to those people who oppose the Bills certain rights in relation to proposing the types of cases, including the No case, to be put into the pamphlet. It is also important to consult with those people who are proposing the No case so that they feel that the question being put on the ballot paper is a fair and accurate depiction of what they believe the legislation is about. I am not sure whether, by negotiation, one would ever come to an agreement on that matter. I merely raise the issue about the first amemdment, where the dominant context of the Bill refers to senators' terms. Yet the depiction of the Bill-not only under the Australian Labor Party but also under the Fraser Government-was in fact sold as simultaneous elections.
—That is both the short and long title.

—That is both the short and long title the Fraser Government used and it is both the short and long title the Hawke Government used. I am still not at all sure that that is what the Bill is about but I will accept that that may very well be the final intent as to what should happen--
—That is why the proposed regulation is more satisfactory. It refers to that.

—But I still believe that since it is unlikely in that type of debate ever to be able to reach the magic consensus so desired and longed for by everybody, it is far better as a matter of principle that that debate be had in the Committee stage of the Bill. The Committee will then be able to deal with what will go on to the ballot paper, because surely what goes on to the ballot paper is of fundamental importance in terms of what people understand it is that they are voting for.

speech.para: So I believe at the moment that there is a fair amount of confusion, unfortunately, about this Bill, most of which I think has been generated by the amendments the Government itself has now brought forward at the dying time of the procedures. It seems to me very odd that it should have done so, as this Bill has been around since May when I first circulated the original Australian Democrat amendments. It is very difficult with an important Bill such as this to be confronted with such amendments at this stage, on the run, which may have ramifications not only for the referenda questions on 25 February but also for referenda basically until the Act is again changed at any time in the future.

So I appeal to the Government not only to look at what it might perceive as being in its own interests in the short term but also to look at the fact that as the wheel turns, as it inevitably does in politics, the Opposition parties, as they are now, will once again be in government and doubtless themselves at some stage be proposing referenda of their own. At that stage the Labor Party will be in opposition and may be very concerned about what it has done in government. So, I hope we get a chance, before we get to the Committee stage, to go through and sort out what I think is now a very murky area in relation to all three elements that I have raised.

speech.speaker: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

talk.start.para: —I cannot allow this opportunity to pass without making some mention of the importance of the Referendum ( Constitution Alteration) Amendment Bill 1983 to the people of the Northern Territory, of the Australian Capital Territory and of Jervis Bay, for it proposes that in future they will have the right to vote in referenda. So, this Bill is of considerable significance to those people. Prior to the action from which this legislation flows, the people of these Territories-and I think I can speak on behalf of them-were very resentful of the fact that when a referendum was held they were denied the opportunity available to electors of the States to cast their votes as to the future of Australia and its Constitution. People in the north-I speak particularly of the Northern Territory-saw decisions being made by a process in which they could not participate. I believe this fact is quite obvious too to the people who are flocking to the Northern Territory now. People living in the southern States had the opportunity to participate fully in decisions reached at referendums concerning Australia. Once they came to the Territory and joined the electors of the Northern Territory they became second class citizens. This state of affairs has been resented fiercely over the years. On days when referendums were held there were many demonstrations by the people to indicate their displeasure. At the referendum in 1977, the Australian people voted overwhelmingly to allow electors of the Territories to participate in referendums. The people of the Northern Territory were very pleased at that vote and have shown their gratitude. Once this Bill has been passed by the Parliament and is enacted, the people of the Territories will be able to participate in all referendums including those that are to be put to the people in February next year. The achievement of this right, in common with many other constitutional steps that have been taken affecting the Territory over the years, is a considerable milestone.

speech.para: Let me look back very briefly-and I will be brief-in chronological order at the events that have taken place in this respect in the Territory. By very slow degrees, constitutional changes have occurred to allow the people to participate in the decision-making processes that have been available to the other citizens of Australia. The Northern Territory was first settled in 1824. It was part of New South Wales from that year until 1863 when, by letters patent, it was annexed to South Australia from New South Wales. In 1868, the towns of Palmerston, Southport, Virginia and Daly were surveyed. In 1869, Palmerston was selected as the site for the chief town in the Northern Territory.

It is interesting to note that, in 1890, the Northern Territory voters were enfranchised through two members of the South Australian Parliament as part of the electorate of Grey. In 1901, at Federation, the Northern Territory became part of the Federal electorate of Grey. In 1911, the Northern Territory passed from South Australia to Commonwealth jurisdiction under the Northern Territory Acceptance Act (No. 20 of 1910). I presume that between 1901 and 1911, the electors of the Northern Territory, then belonging to the South Australian electorate of Grey, had some representation in the Senate and perhaps-I have not been able to ascertain whether this was the case-very briefly in that period they had the opportunity to participate in a referendum. However, in 1911, with the Territory being passed to the Commonwealth of Australia came that period when the Northern Territory had all its rights removed. One could say that they were people without a soul. They were citizens of Australia yet they could not participate in its government. They had no franchise whatsoever.

In 1923, the Northern Territory obtained a seat in the House of Representatives but the member had very restricted voting rights. In 1939, the Darwin Town Management Board was formed. In 1945, the Northern Territory (Administration) Act was set up; a legislative council was formed; and elections were held in that year. It is interesting to note that this measure which was taken to give the people of the Territory some small say in their own affairs was described in those days as the seven/six treatment. Seven people who were departmental heads and public servants were nominated to the Council. Six people from the Northern Territory were elected to that body. The six elected representatives of the people of the Northern Territory said that the seven departmental heads and public servants who were nominated to the council hit them very solidly and refused them their very many requests. This was caused by the seven/six treatment.

talk.start.para: —Nothing has changed.
—It has changed, Senator Harradine, but very, very slowly. At least the people in the Northern Territory--
—I mean in Canberra, not the Northern Territory.

—I must say that it took many years to shake off the yoke of Canberra, and it has not been quite shaken off yet; but we have fine hopes and great expectations for the future. In 1959, the Northern Territory Federal member was granted voting rights in the House of Representatives. Imagine that now! It took that many years before the member for the Northern Territory could stand up in his own right and speak and vote on behalf of the people. In 1969, there was a further constitutional measure in the Northern Territory by which to the new legislative body eight members were elected and six departmental heads and three non-official members were appointed. This measure was taken from the New South Wales colonial practices of some 100 years ago. Still, the Northern Territory progressed by degrees.

speech.para: In 1973, the Joint Committee on the Northern Territory was established by the Federal Parliament to examine constitutional reform. Its report was most helpful . In 1974, the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly sat for the first time as a fully elected body. That was a tremendous milestone. In 1975, as honourable senators would know, for the first time, two Northern Territory people were elected to the Senate. In 1977, it was announced that the Northern Territory would have self-government from 1 July 1979. So, from that date, the Northern Territory became a self-governing territory in most matters.

I note that when this Bill was introduced in the House of Representatives the then Special Minister of State, Mr Young, said that the Government was pleased to state that as a result of the referendum, which followed a decision in legislative form passed by both Houses, the denial to electors of the Northern Territory of the right to vote in referendums was being rectified. The situation as it will stand after this legislation is enacted is that the electors of the Northern Territory will be able to vote in referendums although there are still some differences between their position and that of the electors of the States of Australia. For the people in the Northern Territory the proposal now is that their votes shall be counted, and I quote from the second reading speech:

. . . only as part of the national vote-that is to say, they would not be regarded as being part of any of the States or of determining the majority view of the States but they would contribute to the determination of the majority view of the nation.
The votes of people in the Territories will be counted in the national count. Of course, the Territories as such will not have any bearing on the outcome of a referendum.

That brings me to the last point, the very slow process that I have enumerated over the years by which the people of the Northern Territory have gradually been given more say in their affairs and the affairs of Australia. The next step, of course, to put the people of the north on a par with the people in the States is for the Northern Territory to become a State. I will not speak at length on that matter. However, the population of the Northern Territory is increasing at three times the national average partly because thousands of young people are being attracted by the developments that are taking place. The population of the Northern Territory is increasing by half as much again as the increase in the population of, say, Queensland. Many people are flocking to the Northern Territory to help, together with the present population, the development of that region. Therefore, because of the increase in population and the industrial development I foresee that it will not be very long before the people of the Northern Territory will be looking for further constitutional change as the final step to statehood. When that happens they will then be able to claim for the first time to be on the same footing as our cousins in the six States of Australia. I support the Bill. As I have said before, it will give much pleasure to people of the Territories. I believe there will be much celebration in the Northern Territory in February when the people of the territory vote on the five referendum points because this ability to vote on referenda is a further milestone in the development of the Territory.

speech.speaker: Walters Sen M.S.

talk.start.para: —I am delighted that the Referendum ( Constitution Alteration) Amendment Bill 1983 seeks to give Territory electors the right to vote in referendums. However, problems associated with the referendums have only recently come to light. The original legislation enshrined the principle that there should be an equal and fair opportunity for both sides of a referendum to be put to the Australian people. Until now all governments have abided by the aim of the legislation. The previous Government put a similar question to the Australian people in the simultaneous elections referendum. However, that Government did not try in an underhand fashion to get the referendum through. It tried to present the arguments in a fair and just way and abided by the legislation that has existed since Federation. The important provisions of that legislation state that the Australian Electoral Office must put both sides of the case in every person's post box. Members of parliament who vote for the proposals have the right to put the Yes case. Those who vote against the constitutional amendments have the right to put the No case. The Electoral Office puts together and prints the cases and is responsible for distributing them to every household in Australia. That is the basis of our democracy.

speech.para: Our democracy is based on the belief that changes to the Constitution should be carried out in a fair and just way. As I said, this has been the case until now. However, the present Government has adopted different tactics. In the most underhand way available it has made two vital changes to this practice. The Senate passed the Appropriation Bills on 18 November. Just four days later on the 22nd of the same month the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) put out a news release which told the Australian people that an additional $1.25m of taxpayer's money would be spent on the Yes case alone. He did not tell us this was going to happen before the Appropriation Bills were passed in this place. He announced it several days later. The Appropriation Bills were passed on 18 November; he made this announcement on 22 November. He dares to tell me that I am wrong in saying that the Government has been underhand. This is the first time ever that additional taxpayers' money has been spent on one side of a case for an alteration of the Constitution.

talk.start.para: —How much is Robin Gray going to spend? How much are Joh and Robin going to spend?

—There is no way that that sort of interjection will help the Attorney one bit. In 1977 the Australian Labor Party and the Liberal Party spent large sums of money on the Yes case for the simultaneous elections proposal. The people who put the No case scraped together a small amount of money, and we were still able to defeat the referendum.

speech.para: On 30 November Senator Jessop asked the Attorney-General why it was that the Government was spending this additional money. The Attorney-General said that it was for the good of the people. He said:

It would be quite irresponsible for the Government not to provide positive support for constitutional changes which would provide this country with more efficient and stable government particularly when the changes in question have support, not just of one party, but from all the major parties in this country.

That is Big Brother 1984 at its worst. The Attorney thinks it is in the best interests of the country to alter the Constitution. There are honourable senators in this place who support the No case because they do not believe the alterations will be in the best interests of the country. Yet, the Attorney says : 'It does not really matter what the other senators in this place say. It does not matter what the legislation says about putting both sides in a fair and just way. We will appropriate $1.25m to put just one side of the case. In his answer to Senator Jessop he went on that Australia's record of failed referendums is appalling because of the absence of strong campaigning on the Yes side. He went on:
When one is spending $21.5m on the conduct of the referendumn, the additional one and a bit million dollars that is proposed for this, by comparison, seems eminently worth spending.

His opinion is certainly not the opinion of those honourable senators who support the No case in the proposed referendum. As I say, this is a typical Labor Government underhand method of fighting a battle. It cannot fight in a fair and democratic way. It fights in the underhand way which it has shown very clearly on this occasion. We were told in the other place by the Special Minister of State (Mr Beazley) that it was for the good of the people that the Government was spending taxpayers' money on the Yes case alone. The Attorney- General was also asked a supplementary question as to where the money was to come from. In Hansard of 30 November, he is recorded as saying:
The appropriation in question will come out of, as I understand it, the appropriation for the Department of the Special Minister of State.

He went on in his normal sarcastic fashion to tell Senator Jessop that he could pursue this matter with as much vigour as he could muster when it came to the next round of Estimates. The money does not come out of the appropriation for the Department of the Special Minister of State; it comes out of the appropriation for the Department of the Attorney-General and indeed, it comes out of the slush fund of the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins). The Minister for Finance has been appropriated $53m this year. During the Estimates Committee hearing we were unable to establish where that $53m was going to be spent. No wonder we were not able to find out where that $53m was going. The Government was keeping it very hush-hush. The Government was not game to tell the Senate before the Appropriation Bills were passed where that $53m was to be spent. We were told it was to be spent in all sorts of areas. We were told that social welfare was to get $20m of that $53m and various other departments were told that they were due to receive special amounts out of the slush fund of the Minister for Finance.

But not one word was mentioned about the Government spending $1.25m on the Yes case alone for the referendum. That was kept very quietly hidden by the Government until the Appropriation Bills had been passed through this place. Indeed, the Appropriation Bills would never have been passed, because the Australian Democrats would have joined us, had we known that the Government was acting in such an underhand fashion. But there is more to this matter than just that amount of money. Section 14A (1) of the Referendum (Constitution Alteration ) Act states:
The ballot-paper to be used for the purposes of a referendum may be in accordance with Form C in the Schedule.
Form C in the Schedule to the Act sets out very clearly what a multiple question ballot paper should be like. It is very clear. Under the directions on how to vote, the ballot paper states:
DIRECTIONS: Mark your vote on this ballot-paper as follows:
If you APPROVE the proposed law, write the word Yes in the space provided opposite the question.
If you DO NOT APPROVE the proposed law, write the word No in the space provided opposite the question.
Without our knowledge, the Government brought down a new regulation altering the ballot paper in the Act.

talk.start.para: —It was with your knowledge. I told the shadow Attorney.
—We had no idea that the alteration would be set out as it has been. The revised ballot paper states:

speech.para: You must indicate ''YES'' or ''NO'' to EACH of the FIVE proposed constitutional alterations set out below.

Does a tick indicate yes or no? Does a cross indicate yes or no? Has this alteration been made to pick up the nearly 2 per cent of informal votes which normally accompany a referendum so that the Government will not have any informal votes? What is it on about? The new ballot paper states:
You must indicate ''YES'' or ''NO''.

I would like the Attorney-General to tell me whether, if a person were to put a cross and nothing else, a cross would indicate yes or no. If a person placed a tick, what would that do? The whole thing is too ludicrous. The alteration has obviously been made so that the Attorney-General will not have any informal votes but will be able to interpret the crosses and the ticks as he so chooses. Apart from that, he has proposed an alteration to the original ballot paper which every government has used since Federation. No other government has tried this sleight-of-hand. Every other government has used the format printed in the Schedule in the Act. The original ballot paper asks:
Do you approve the proposed law for the alteration of the Constitution entitled . . .

Then the title of the proposed law is set out. The Attorney-General does not think that that is quite good enough. That question would not put his side of the case clearly enough, so he proposes to alter it. The revised ballot paper states:
The proposed laws which make these alterations are, in order:
1: SIMULTANEOUS ELECTIONS: To ensure that elections for the Senate and the House of Representatives are always held on the same day, and to adjust the terms of Senators accordingly.
DO YOU APPROVE THE PROPOSED ALTERATION?

I do not accept that interpretation of simultaneous elections. None of the people who voted no to the Constitution Alteration (Simultaneous Elections) Bill accept that as a description of simultaneous elections. There is a lot more to it. In regard to parliamentary terms, the Attorney-General's proposed ballot paper states:
2: PARLIAMENTARY TERMS: To extend the maximum life of Parliaments from 3 to 4 years.
DO YOU APPROVE THE PROPOSED ALTERATION?

That is the Attorney-General's interpretation, once again. It is not the interpretation of those putting the No case. There is no mention of an 8-year term for the Senate-not one word. He thinks this proposal will go down well if the people feel that it involves a four-year term and nothing else. It is the most underhand move I have ever experienced in this Parliament. No previous government would have sullied itself by this sort of act. The proposed ballot paper defines 'interchange of powers' as follows:
3: INTERCHANGE OF POWERS: To enable the Commonwealth and States to refer powers to each other by mutual agreement.
What does the new ballot paper say about the advisory jurisdiction powers of the High Court? It states:
4: ADVISORY JURISDICTION OF HIGH COURT: To enable the Commonwealth, the States and the Northern Territory more easily to obtain from the High Court its views on certain constitutional questions.
DO YOU APPROVE THE PROPOSED ALTERATION?

There has been no consultation at all between the Government and those senators who voted no to the Bill which recommended that change in the Constitution. There was no consultation whatever. We had no idea that the regulations had been made. We made no input in regard to the description of the various questions. The Attorney-General has framed them as he wishes them to be framed. We have decided that the original names of the Bills in question ought to remain, because we do not believe we could ever come to an agreement with the Attorney- General on the description terms.

talk.start.para: —There was a lot of point in consulting them, wasn't there?

—The Attorney-General has already made that statement in an interjection. When Senator Macklin was commenting on the need for consultation, the Attorney-General said that in no way would there be consultation. That was his interjection, so Senator Evans should not be so pious with me. Allocating money after the Appropriation Bills were passed and the way in which the Government has changed the ballot papers, with no reference at all to those who voted no to the Bills, are typical examples of what this Government calls consensus.
—Oh, Senator!

—Well, I would like Senator Button to tell me when he has approached any member of the Senate who voted no on the description of any of those questions. If he has not, he should not try to tell me that there is any consensus in his Government at all. I turn now to the amendments proposed by the Government. We find that the Government is not too darned clear about its legal right to alter the regulations. It has proposed a couple of amendments in case it finds that it has not the necessary powers. Senator Gareth Evans says: 'We are just being cautious'.
—Wise counsel.

—I would say that the Government has had very wise counsel because it has not the power at all to alter the regulations. Indeed, it will be on that ground that we will be fighting them. I believe that the Government has done its cause a tremendous amount of harm. The people of Australia will have knowledge of this. The proceedings of the Senate are not being broadcast today. I appeal to the media to note what has occurred because it is only through the media that we can get justice in this; only through the media can we get out to the Australian people knowledge of the shonky and underhand methods that the Government has adopted in regard to this particular referendum. Never before has a government used such tactics, but Senator Gareth Evans says: 'We are using them because it is for the good of the people and we know; we are Big Brother 1984'. The Senate will no doubt be discussing this matter after the suspension for dinner, at the Committee stage.

speech.speaker: Missen Sen A.J.

talk.start.para: —I wish to speak on the Referendum (Constitution Alteration) Amendment Bill 1983 and the proposed amendments thereto. I hope that I will be more dispassionate in dealing with them than my colleague Senator Walters who has just sat down. I think that sound arguments and criticisms can be made but I do not think there is any need to talk about slush funds and I believe that some of the arguments used were taken to the extreme. A good criticism or argument becomes absurd if given more than its proper weight. The Bill itself is, of course, desirable. Its basic purpose is to provide a capacity to vote, and a procedure for voting, in the Territories as was approved by referendum in 1977. Heaven only knows why it has taken all this time to get these matters before the Parliament. It would have been much better if done at an earlier stage. It is, of course, in regard to other aspects that criticisms have been raised. One of the problems in dealing with such matters as this is that one gets things on the run. I heard only this morning about certain amendments being moved and have seen some documents and amendments only within the last hour. That is very unfortunate but probably one of the characteristics of the end of the session. When dealing with matters, one does not have a full time to look at the implications of all amendments and, therefore, to consider carefully what one should do about them.

speech.para: I wish to refer to two matters in particular because my views on them obviously are not entirely in accord with those of my colleague who has just sat down. I believe that there is substantial cause for complaint to lead one to vote for the proposed amendments. I want to deal first with those that are proposed by the Opposition and by the Australian Democrats in respect of the proposed expenditure of $1.25m, which is not very much in budgetary terms. I can understand and sympathise with the contention that the history of referenda in this country has shown that it is much easier for small groups who are in opposition to raise money and therefore to be heard. Probably they will get much more media coverage in the course of the campaign; they generally do. That was my experience when travelling with the former Prime Minister during the 1977 referendum campaign. The Prime Minister would speak to a meeting of about 1,000 people, for example, somewhere in north Queensland and would get about three lines publicity in the paper but an opposing senator might sneak into town, be interviewed by a radio station and prompt a long article on the subject in the paper next day. In certain places, of course, the local media will have particular prejudices and preferences. I have no doubt that that will occur in the course of this referendum campaign, which does not relate, of course, to any transfer of powers from the States to the Commonwealth, rather with the better administration of Government of this country. It deals also with the provision of facilities from which the States will benefit substantially, in regard to both the question of advisory opinions of the High Court-a facility that the Court has never had before-and the interchange of powers, which will clear up a lot of matters that have been a worry and will provide both for the Commonwealth to transfer powers to the States and for the States safely to transfer powers to the Commonwealth. I am sure those advantages will be overlooked and there will be a screaming campaign on the part of the no voters, asserting that somehow this has to do with the transference of powers to the Commonwealth. All the old arguments will be trotted out.

One must bear in mind the support that these referenda proposals enjoy, including that of the leaders of the two major opposition parties, recognising that there are dissenting groups in each case. Also it must be recognised that they have been undertaken at the behest of the Constitutional Convention. The Government has resiled from its original fixed term preference to take up the proposals that the non-Labor members of the Convention insisted should be the alternative. In our election campaign early this year Mr Fraser himself undertook to submit referendum proposals in regard to four year terms and simultaneous elections. No doubt, had we won government, we would now be making these proposals. Therefore, I can understand the feeling on the part of the Government that the Yes cases do not get very much money spent on them, that there is a tendency always for small groups to get an exaggerated amount of attention. Therefore, this money should be provided. I understand my colleague's objection in principle to that.

Of course, all kinds of expenditures will be made by governments during the course of the referenda campaign. It is a certainty that the Premier of Queensland and his Government will campaign and will spend a lot of government money in urging the No case. Probably the same will occur in Tasmania. Undoubtedly the Premier of Queensland will use his plane; he will not be lending it to anyone else, I am sure. He will be travelling around and, with other people, will be campaigning at government expense. Of course, provision is already made, and will be in the case of every such referendum, for an equal distribution of the Yes and No cases. Regardless of how few may have voted no in the Parliament-in some cases the No votes amounted to three to five only-the No case will have an opportunity to be heard equal to that of the Yes case. I understand the objection that this proposed further expenditure might be regarded as giving unfair weight to the Yes case. It would perhaps have been better if the Government had instead allocated the proposed expenditure as between the Yes and No cases, upon the basis of the number of members of parliament who voted for them respectively. If such a distribution of the money were made I suppose that very little argument could be advanced against it. It would perhaps be fairer than providing for the making of only one payment. However, I understand the reasons it is being done. I think it unfortunate that it has gone to this stage, although I do not accept some of the more exaggerated things that have been said about it.

A second matter is in regard to the regulations to prescribe the form of ballot . I think there is more cause for concern here. It is doubtful whether the regulations, as they stand in the principal Act, justify the making of regulations in this form. It is a very short regulation-making clause. I understand that always it has been the long title which has been used. It would be better if, in fact, more care were taken in the choice of the long title so that it reflected precisely what the Bill was doing. It would then be dealt with in the Parliament and we could vote on it, we could amend it. Unfortunately, when it is done by regulation, the result must be that the regulations cannot be disallowed by the Parliament because there will be no time in which to do so.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

talk.start.para: —Before the suspension of the sitting, I dealt with what seems to be a major objection to the Bill. I refer to the expenditure of money on the Yes case and the amendments which are proposed by the Opposition in that regard. I had turned to another matter, namely, the criticism which is made of the regulation-making power. This is now to be found in the amendments circulated by the Government. I have said that I believe that the current regulation power under the principal Act would not be adequate to cover what is proposed in regard to prescribing the form in which the questions will be put to the electors. Previously, the long title was always used. I have already said that I think more care should be taken-and it should have been taken in this Bill-to see that the long title is one which very clearly sets out what is involved in the Bill and does not prejudice one side or the other in emphasising the features of a proposal and ignoring what might be its drawbacks.

speech.para: I think it is better on the whole that these provisions should be in the Bill itself and that the Parliament therefore should have the opportunity of voting and amending the Bill. The problem with regard to the Attorney's proposal that the regulations prescribing the forms of ballot papers may be made is that we cannot be sure of the form of those regulations. I have seen a draft from the Attorney this afternoon which suggests the way in which the regulations will set out the titles, differing from the long title. Some of the proposed ways for the descriptions to be put before the electors are better and clearer than at present. But I think that at least one is a little deceptive. For example, as raised by other senators, with respect to the proposed four-year term, reference is made only to that of members of the House of Representatives and not to that of senators. I recognise that the proposal with respect to the Senate is the more difficult part of the proposition to sell--

talk.start.para: —It is not deceptive. It talks about the life of parliaments being increased.

—Yes, it talks about the life of parliaments, but if, as in the Attorney's proposal, a change from three-year to four-year terms is mentioned, mention must also be made of what happens in regard to the Senate. I can understand that a proposal for the term of senators to be eight years is not one of the best features from the Yes point of view. We may be able to live with it, but it is obviously one of the drawbacks of the proposal. I am prepared to work very strongly in favour of its being accepted, but the problem is that, if we go away from the public expression in an Act of the Parliament and leave it to regulations, there will be endless debate. If there were time to disallow the regulations or to bring them before the Parliament to be re-argued, that would be different. But as we know the time factor now is such that we are in the last fortnight before the end of the parliamentary session. Therefore, a notice of disallowance of such a regulation would not come on for debate and would not be dealt with.
—You can debate it tonight. I am going to move it as an amendment to the Bill.
—Yes, it is being debated tonight; I agree.
—You can debate it now. I am going to change it and move it as an amendment to the Bill itself. I have been impressed by the argument. You can sit down.

—I agree with that. That means it is subject to debate. We had better have copies of it so that we can consider it and try to improve it. But I agree with the general proposition that the Government has put up that in the past long titles very often have been deceptive and non-explanatory to the electors.
—They were last time.

—Yes, they were last time and I think it is important that we try to reach agreement on them. Therefore, I understand the purpose of the Government in changing this, but I think it is unfortunate that it has come about this way. I think, in future, the long title should be considered more carefully when we are passing the actual Act, knowing that that will be the title which will go before the public. That will achieve the best result. Therefore, I am sorry to say that, although I support the amendment of the Opposition, I am interested in hearing what the Attorney has to say in respect of the change which obviously has been decided upon during the suspension of the sitting. I will leave it at that and say that I generally support the Bill and what it does to bring the opportunities to the Territories to vote in these matters. I trust that not too many red herrings will be allowed to obscure the real issues in the referendum campaign, issues which can stand on their own merits and which should not be obscured by any outside or unnecessary irrelevancies.

speech.speaker: Archer Sen B.R.

talk.start.para: —I will take only a moment to speak on the Referendum (Constitution Alteration) Amendment Bill 1983. I thought it would be inappropriate, and I knew that the Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans, would think it was inappropriate, if I did not express the disgust and contempt that I have for the way in which this matter is being handled. I like the great exhibition of consensus and open democracy that the Government has beaten its breast about for the last few months. Even more, I am appreciative of what an exhibition in deception, misstatement and undemocratic action this is. I also want to give the Attorney-General the opportunity to explain fully how it is that since 1977 he has been able to have such a complete change of heart on some of what he would now call his 'considered views'. When I compare his statements of 1977 with the sorts of things he is trying to ram through in this legislation , I find them difficult to reconcile. The Attorney, being a man of words, by adding a few words here and there will be able to justify this change.

speech.para: If the referendum is to be fair and open, if it is even to seem to be fair and open, why not allow it to be held with fair and equal presentation. I want the Attorney-General again to try to demonstrate why he wants to prevent the cases from having equal presentation. It would be fair if they were to have such equal presentation. I am not at any stage disappointed about this; I am just plain disgusted. It strikes me that we have another of those cases in which the Government has come forward with a few more amendments. This is what I also gather the Attorney referred to earlier today as 'wise counsel'; I think to those on this side it really means that he is trying to botch it up again. It can only be likened to that frivolous mess that we wound up in when discussing the sex discrimination legislation under much the same circumstances. I believe it would be far better if these things were given a bit of proper consideration in the first place and were presented in a form which is fair and reasonable. In fact, when it comes to being fair and reasonable, I presume that the Attorney has seen some of the editorial comment which has already appeared. It does not appear to indicate that he is getting his point across or that the legislation in its present form is saleable. I do not think it is too late to ask the Attorney-General at least to reconsider the position and come up with the only fair decision possible, that is, that the matter be treated fairly and that both sides of the argument be given an equal opportunity at government expense to come before the people of Australia.

speech.speaker: Watson Sen J.O.W.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak briefly on the Referendum ( Constitution Alteration) Amendment Bill 1983 for two purposes. Firstly, I wish to raise two issues with the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans), which arise from the inclusion of certain voters from the Northern Territory. Secondly , I place on record my position in relation to the referendum proposals. I was not in the Senate for all the voting that took place with respect to the referendum proposals, as I was the deputy leader of the Australian delegation attending the Inter- Parliamentary Union conference in Seoul at the time. Therefore, I wish to state quite clearly my position in relation to those referendum proposals, because I think there has been some confusion in the media 's reporting of where I stand on them. I wish to give notice that I am firmly behind the attitude of the Premier of Tasmania, Robin Gray, in supporting a No case. This technical Bill is designed to facilitate the referendum which will take place on 25 February next. I must also deplore the Government's attitude in allocating money to only one side, $1.25m to the Yes case. This is an additional amount, which is directed only to the Yes case. The argument for this is that there will be plenty of money coming from other sources to support a No case. I do not think this is the argument. Our traditional position in Australia in relation to referendums is to give equal weight to both the Yes case and the No case. It is a matter of history and fact that Australians tend when in doubt, to vote No. Despite the fact that the questions that are to be put to the electors are designed to solicit a Yes answer, I think many Australians, if not given an adequate explanation, on a prima facie reading of the referendum Bills would be inclined to vote Yes.

speech.para: As my colleagues Senator Archer and Senator Walters mentioned earlier, these are some of the insidious features of the Bill. The Government's intentions are not entirely clear to the electorate, purely by a simple reading of the questions that are intended to be placed upon the referendum sheet. Many Australians would welcome a four-year term, rather than a three-year term, but a lot more would reject an eight-year term for senators. It would be far too long a term. For example, it would give a non-performer too long an opportunity to remain listless on the back bench. There is a need to be motivated by the needs of the electorate. It would tend to put too many senators far too far removed from the feelings of the electorate.

On the other hand, the Bill could be read by many in the community as a continuation of a transfer of powers away from the States and to the Federal Government, thus creating an increase in central responsibilities and central directions, and an increase in the powers of the Federal Government to the detriment of the States. I would totally deplore that.

To be successful, the referendum must be passed not only by a majority of voters but also by a majority of States. Without looking too hard into the crystal ball, at this stage I believe that Tasmania would certainly be voting No .
