The Sex Discrimination Bill consists of 106 clauses. It has a Schedule attached to it-The breathed-on U.N. Convention on the matter.
Between the Bill and the Convention the only discrimination between man and woman that is not extinguished is the difference.

But then there is another splendid assurance within our sight. 'Woman' means a member of the female sex irrespective of age. Is it that the servant in Shakespeare's King Lear was in error when he argued: 'Women will all turn monsters'?
Using language which would have been shunned by Boadicea, the Bill proscribes the areas of discrimination.
For even the 'part-emancipated mind', the proscriptions are laughable.
'The aim of a Federation', said the great Mr Deakin, 'is to found a nation'.
Perfectly true, but nations are not to be constructed, protected, their cause furthered by ridiculous resorts to legislative nonsense.
I am sorry he did not finish up there, but he goes on to say:
The common law and the criminal codes of the States are not lacking in authority-
that is what Senator Lewis said and I support it--
and sanction with respect to assault of improper physical advancement. But no, the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 seeks to erect its own rockery of discipline.
Is a wink at a bus conductress, the sending of flowers to a hostess, the helping of a woman across a street, 'sexual harassment'?

One has to ask the question because one never knows; it may be regarded as such. The way the Government brings these things in without a thought makes me very concerned. But then perhaps I do not understand the attitudes or the minds of Senator Ryan and others. My wife seems to be quite happy with her lot. She believes it is quite important for me to open the door for her and all those things-the graces, the traditional behaviour that has come to be expected. I have serious reservations about this legislation. I propose to support the amendments put forward by the Opposition and by Senator Harradine when the time comes and will reserve my final decision until later.

speech.speaker: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

talk.start.para: —I want to use the opportunity provided by the second reading debate on the Sex Discrimination Bill (No. 2) to put forward some points for consideration. We have heard a lot of debate about this Bill and we all know that it is the second Bill that has been brought forward which includes-
—The third.
—I beg Senator Harradine's pardon; the third Bill. But it is called the Sex Discrimination Bill (No. 2).
—I am sorry, it is the second.

—It includes well over 50 amendments to date and we have heard that the Opposition is bringing forward some more, and so is Senator Harradine; so there will be plenty of amendments to it. In my opinion, after reading it, I think that the best amendment of all would be to forget about it. I do not think the Bill is necessary. If we lived in the Middle East, I would certainly say that it was necessary. This legislation is designed, according to the Bill, to outlaw discrimination on grounds of sex, marital status or pregnancy in the areas of employment, education, accommodation, provision of goods, facilities and services, disposal of land, activities of clubs and the administration of Federal laws and programs. However, in effect, I sincerely believe that it will do no more than create divisions and long term conflict, not just among women but between men and women, religious groups, families and employers.

speech.para: Most people support justice for all. Regardless of sex, male and female should receive equal pay for equal work. Actually, an Act was passed in 1974 which guaranteed equal pay for equal work. Until then the basic wage was determined on the needs of a man, his wife and two children. The judge, Mr Justice Moore, in granting equal pay, recommended that the Government find some other way to compensate families where the father was the sole breadwinner. This has never been done. In fact, single income families pay much more tax than the two income families with the same gross income. Each wage earner is allowed to earn $4,000 tax free. The two income family gets $8,000 tax free. Even with the spouse rebate, the single income family pays much more tax than if both the father and mother went out to work. I understand that Senator Walters will move an amendment to deal with that aspect. I believe that there should be equal opportunity in education and for training for employment in occupations of choice for both men and women. Most people would support the general principle of providing employment, accommodation, finance, et cetera, without discrimination on the grounds of sex. However, this Bill goes far beyond that and raises concern on several different grounds.

It must be realised that any anti-discrimination in favour of some must discriminate against someone else. While accepting the justice of women being equally eligible for work, education and financial recompense as men, forcing employers, education authorities and the Public Service to ignore pregnancy, de facto relationships and the best interests of children is not acceptable to many and makes some of us very concerned. This Bill aims at changes in moral and social values that I do not think should be included. It will infringe on civil liberties of employers when affirmative action is introduced. This has been promised by the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) in two years time. Actually I was at a Senate committee meeting at which Senator Giles was also present. Senator Giles said that affirmative action would be mandatory. I feel this would take away from employers the right to hire and fire. Under clause 29 of the Bill, positive discrimination in respect of a previously so- called disadvantaged sex will be lawful.

The Minister has already been reported as saying that future Federal Public Service hiring will favour women and that her own Department will begin favouring women in its promotion and management policies. I do not agree with that. Actually, in principle, I feel that affirmative action seems to be artificially creating quotas for women in the Public Service and elsewhere. That is a form of discrimination against otherwise qualified people. In the end, I feel that it will be harmful to the cause of equality of opportunity.

The Bill introduces legislation which, by giving preference to women in the paid work force and de facto situations, undermines the family unit. It represents an attack on the freedom of choice for women to stay at home or to go out to work in that it supports the preamble to the Convention which states:
The full and complete development of a country, the welfare of the world, and the course of peace, require the maximum participation of women on equal terms with men in all fields.

I think we are starting to see some of that in the jobs that women are being given when money is being allocated for the Commonwealth employment program. Half of the jobs have to be for women. It does not matter what sorts of jobs they are. Councils are complaining because half of the jobs have to be given to women. If honourable senators opposite want to go out and work on roads, that is up to them. I remember that once when I was in Singapore I saw women carting big bags of cement on their shoulders. I felt sorry for them. Before long, that will be happening in Australia. Article 10 (c) of the Convention refers to the elimination of any stereotyped concept of the roles of men and women at all levels and in all forms of education. This stereotyped concept which must be eliminated refers to the mother-father role by which families have been nurtured for generations and which certain people would like to see destroyed.

Article 5 (a) of the Convention calls upon governments to modify the social and cultural patterns of conduct of men and women. Article 10 (c) calls for the revision of textbooks and school programs and the adaption of teaching methods with the object of the elimination of any stereotyped concept of the roles of men and women at all levels and in all forms of education. I feel that this is nothing short of social engineering.

Australia ratified a legally-binding international treaty on 29 July 1983 pledging to use our education system to eliminate these roles. Specific measures include re-writing school books and teaching methods to present only non-sexist roles. I feel that this is quite wrong. Any pictures or stories of a mother and children waving good-bye to daddy going off to work will be banned.

talk.start.para: —Nonsense.

—I read that in the newspaper and I believe it is true. As I said, it is social engineering. Similarly, article 5 of the Convention refers to family education including a proper understanding of maternity as a social function. Who will dictate what is a proper understanding of 'maternity' in this context? In all of this, it seems that the implication is that women are not fulfilling their roles as citizens unless they are in the work force. That is an implication that I strongly reject. Women at home looking after families are in the work force. I believe they are doing an excellent job. Somebody said to me when I came to the Senate: 'Oh, you have gone to work now?' I said: 'Get that out of your head. I worked a jolly lot harder probably when I was at home rearing my children'. Anyone who is at home looking after a husband and children is doing an excellent job.

speech.para: I do not see why we want to do away with the concept of women being at home with families. I do not see why we want to get into the habit of women having to take over men's jobs. Over the years, men have been recognised as the breadwinners and many women were happy to stay at home to look after their families. Actually, I have a quote from the Prime Minister. In Federal Parliament on 10 May, Bob Hawke said:

. . . I accept the point that we must not, in our enthusiasm to eliminate those forms of discrimination, ignore the fact that a very large number of women see the total fulfillment of their aspirations and their happiness in terms of the family-the role of wife and mother, of sustainer and supporter, and the upbringing of children. It is a noble and appropriate role for those who see their total fulfilment in it.
I notice honourable senators sitting opposite are all quiet now. The Prime Minister continued:

There is absolutely nothing that this Government will do which will in any way prejudice women who appropriately make that choice. Indeed, the range of policies that will be adopted by my Government will ensure that families and women discharging that role will be given the greatest opportunity of achieving fulfillment and satisfaction for them and those dependent on them.
They are noble ideas, but I cannot find them contained in this Bill.

I refer to another aspect of the Bill which Archbishop Carroll touched on in his letter to the Prime Minister. I notice that a number of other senators are favouring Archbishop Carroll in their comments on this Bill. I have heard him mentioned already by Senator Lewis--

talk.start.para: —Not many on the other side.
—That is right, Senator Kilgariff. Archbishop Carroll said:

speech.para: In requiring all people in so many areas of activity to treat persons in de facto relationships on terms of equality with married persons, the Bill, I believe, denigrates the institution of marriage in our society very seriously indeed. In this connection, would it be unlawful for a landlord who advertised a house to let to accept as tenants a married couple in preference to a de facto couple solely on the basis of marital status? The convention does not seem to me to create any international obligation to legitimate, as it were, de facto relationships and to place them on a footing of equality with marriage.

Would it be unlawful for a doctor or nurse to decline to perform an abortion? Some amendments no doubt cover this. I have received petition after petition and , no doubt, we have heard them being presented in the Senate day after day requesting that the Bill be amended to prevent it from being used in support of deliberately procured abortions. Of course, in common with many others in the Senate, I have received a tremendous number of letters and petitions asking that this Bill be not passed, asking that the Convention be not ratified, wanting a referendum and complaining that there was no referendum before the Convention was ratified. However, I do believe that in most cases women can get where they want if they have the ability. There are now women in Australia who drive buses, taxis, trams, racing cars and 50-tonne trucks. There are racehorse jockeys, apprentice electricians, mechanics and air traffic controllers.

talk.start.para: —In Queensland? Disgraceful!

—I have never said it is disgraceful at all. They can get these jobs and keep them. My husband has a woman pilot and she does a very good job. There are women judges, business executives, managers and of course politicians. There are thirteen women in the Senate and if we had been discriminated against we would not be here either to talk about this famous Bill . I tend to think that there are few remaining barriers against women in Australia in jobs, commercial contracts, politics and social life, and the barriers that do exist stem mainly from traditional attitudes built into society and not easily changed by law. In areas where there is discrimination, let us have specific legislation to deal with specific problems, not an all- encompassing Bill which ties us to the United Nations. We all know what being tied to the United Nations means. We saw that in relation to the Tasmanian dam. That is something we should think about. Actually, the Australian Constitution gives the Federal Government power to overrule the States on any matter on which it has an international treaty. Just as the Tasmanian Government was prevented from building a dam as the Federal Government had an international treaty on that issue, so I am very concerned that the sex discrimination treaty will give the Federal Government power to outlaw behaviour which most of us consider to be quite normal.

speech.para: I believe that when governments legislate to give rights to some sections of the community, often the legitimate rights of other section of the community can be taken away. That is one of the effects of this Bill. The Bill comprises the fundamental principles of justice and liberty. Take, for example, clause 74 (2) of the Bill which reverses the traditional onus of proof for an accused person, from innocent until proven guilty to an effective guilty until proven innocent. As well as this, the Bill states that a person appearing before the Commission does not have a right to be represented by a lawyer or solicitor unless the Commission expressly allows it. I wonder where all the civil liberty protesters are now. They are ominously quiet about that, if one asks me.

In my opinion the Bill, itself, is sexist. It promotes a bureaucratic and legalistic approach to the enforcement of morals between the sexes. I find there is a definite contradiction in that on the one hand it maintains that sexual morality, including sexual preference, sexual status and pregnancy, is a private affair but that the manner of acting towards someone of the opposite sex is a matter of public concern and can be regulated by law. The Bill is blatantly sexist in that it assumes that where other factors do not sway judgment and where the sole apparent difference between the two applicants for a job is their sex, the person making the choice must choose on the grounds of sex. I presume, naturally, in this case it would favour the woman.

The Bill says it is to give effect to certain provisions of the United Nations Convention. It does not say, of course, which provisions, but it does provide for a Sex Discrimination Commissioner to deal with, through conciliation, matters that have been complained about. Of course people have been raising the question of who is going to be this famous Sex Discrimination Commissioner. My colleague Senator Boswell asked a question about that in the Senate the other day. If the conciliation attempt fails, the Sex Discrimination Commissioner can refer the matter to the Human Rights Commission. This body may then make a determination and if necessary seek its enforcement by a Federal court.

I do feel that the Bill has very wide implications for all men, women and children in Australia. It is difficult to anticipate the full effect of its implications and of the associated United Nations Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination Against Women. The external affairs power is being used in a deceptive way to bring the United Nations Convention on discrimination into the law in this country. I am concerned that in a time of national difficulty, with high unemployment, inflation and interest rates and with a growing cynicism in the hearts of young people, the Bill does nothing about these problems. This Bill is puting one foot on the sticky paper and when the affirmative action comes in we will have our two feet well and truly placed on that sticky paper. All I say is that I do not think the Bill is necessary and I will support the amendment moved to the second reading motion by the Opposition. I just want to bring these matters and my feelings about the Bill to the attention of the Senate.

speech.speaker: Harradine Sen B.

talk.start.para: —The introduction of the Sex Discrimination Bill (No. 2) calls for some comment from me, despite the fact that I spoke on the second reading stage of the former Bill. This, in effect, is a new Bill and, because it has picked up some of the amendments sought, it does really call for some response from those of us who had been involved in discussions on the subject and had been involved in a deep study of the matter in the hope that the legislation could be so amended as would enable those of us who have a commitment to the abolition of sex discrimination and a commitment to a range of other values to support the measure. I wish to acknowledge the work that has been done and the courtesy that has been shown by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) and I assume, naturally, by the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women (Senator Ryan)-
—A natural assumption.

—I said that-in the discussions that took place. The Prime Minister and the Attorney-General were present, but no doubt the Minister, in the background, was conscious of these matters. I acknowledge their work and their attempt to understand some of the concerns that had been raised and to overcome some of those concerns. They have achieved this only partially, however , and it is my hope that they will see their way clear to come up with other amendments which will get rid of the problems that some people genuinely see. The people who genuinely see those problems do not see them as being in any way associated with bona fide moves to outlaw discrimination against women. I will discuss those points briefly, but before I do it is essential to say something about the question of affirmative action. It was my hope that the Minister may have seen her way clear to bring down the Green Paper on affirmative action so that it could be considered in the whole context of this matter.
—It would be confusing.

—That may or may not be. We have been pretty confused up to this time. But I think it would have been of assistance to honourable senators, who recognise, as the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs said, that there would be need for further legislative action after consideration of the Green Paper had been completed. I will just mention, for the benefit of the Senate, why I am saying this and why I feel that even at this late stage it would be important, not only for the people who are opposed to sex discrimination legislation and the people who support the outlawing of sex discrimination but also for the people who support fully the Bill that is before us. I think it would be of importance if the Green Paper were brought down for discussion. The original private member's Bill which was introduced into this chamber on 26 November 1981 by the present Minister contained provisions for affirmative action. The explanatory memorandum which accompanied that Bill stated:

speech.para: The Bill establishes that various organisations must establish affirmative action plans for women employees-
It went on:
. . . A Director of Affirmative Action is established to advise on the planning and implementing of these affirmative action plans.

That is on page 2 of the explanatory memorandum which accompanied that Bill. Honourable senators will recall that most of what the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills had to say in criticism of that private member's Bill was directed to those affirmative action provisions, particularly in connection with-and I list them:
the absence of review of the guidelines (for affirmative action);
the absence of a statement as to what the 'objects' of that Part of the Bill were;
the absence of provision for a warrant for entry to premises-not just public premises but 'the premises of private bodies'; and
no rights of appeal or compensation in regard to cancellation of contracts.

Now let us come to this year. In a joint statement issued by Senator Ryan and by the Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans, on 11 May 1983 headed 'Sex discrimination legislation for present sitting of Parliament' the Attorney- General and the Minister said-and this was in the shape of an accouncement-that there would be a 'change in the order of events' and that the affirmative action provisions would be preceded by a Green Paper setting out options for further legislation. I repeat that-it is in the third last paragraph-Senator Ryan and Senator Gareth Evans said that in addition to introducing the Sex Discrimination Bill the Government would be issuing a Green Paper setting out options for further legislation which would provide for affirmative action programs to ensure equal employment opportunities. That was in May 1983. This announcement was in fact repeated in the Minister's second reading speech on the Sex Discrimination Bill, which was made to this Parliament on 2 June 1983. On the matter of affirmative action I refer to an article in the Australian Financial Review dated 7 October 1983 in which it was revealed that the contents of the discussion paper were available. The article stated:
In November the Federal Government will release a green paper on affirmative action for women. It-
that is the Federal Government-
plans to bring in legislation in the first parliamentary session next year.
The article then went on to state:

Affirmative action will get its first airing in November when a green paper is due to be released to engender awareness of the issue and it is anticipated a bill will be put through the first session of Parliament next year . . .
The green paper is being prepared for Senator Ryan's office by lawyer Chris Ronalds . . .
The contents of the discussion paper are a closely guarded secret.

This Green Paper was to have been released in November, but on 9 November Senator Ryan, in reply to a question in this chamber, said that although she had a draft of the paper of affirmative action she did not intend to make the draft public 'until the sex discrimination legislation is enacted'. I think the Minister sees affirmative action as part and parcel of the one aim, to eliminate discrimination on the grounds of sex and to right the situations that occur in some areas relating to that matter. If that is so, I believe it would be of benefit to honourable senators and indeed to the Minister's own cause if she could see her way clear to release that discussion paper so that honourable senators and the public could study it in the context of the whole range of legislation that it might evoke and in the context of this legislation. Senator Janine Haines, the Australian Democrat spokesman on women's affairs, said as far back as 13 May:
Lack of understanding about how affirmative action for women works is no justification for excluding this important programme from Senator Susan Ryan's Sex Discrimination Bill.

She was clearly of the view, which I do not necessarily agree with as I have not seen what the Green Paper states, that some such legislation was required and it should have been included in this Sex Discrimination Bill. So it is my view that the Minister, in her own interests and in the interests of the whole of the program, should release this Green Paper.

Let me go on to the matters that I believe are now outstanding. Whilst acknowledging the effort that has been put into this by the Prime Minister, the Attorney-General and the Minister, may I deal briefly with matters that I believe really need clarification, on the one hand, an amendment in the legislation, on the other, before it is, in my view, an acceptable piece of legislation which cannot be used for purposes other than those for which it was designed, namely, the outlawing of sex discrimination.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister repre- senting the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 6 October 1983:

question.para: (1) Is the Government continuing to review the community development employment projects scheme's (CDEP) effectiveness in each State and in the Northern Territory.

answer.speaker: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) A review of the community development employment program (CDEP) by senior officers from the departments of Aboriginal Affairs, Prime Minister and Cabinet, Finance, Social Security and Employment and Industrial Relations was conducted in January, 1983. Reviews of individual CDEPs will be conducted annually, in conjunction with the National Aboriginal Conference (NAC) under the newly developed CDEP operational procedures and policy guidelines.

In addition, the Government has removed the freeze imposed by the previous Government on the number of participants being paid within each funded project to the level of their full unemployment benefit entitlement.

(4) No. The new operational procedures are designed to give communities flexibility in defining the nature of work to be performed under the CDEP scheme .
(5) No. CDEP is an employment-oriented scheme in which the nature of the employment is determined by the community.
(6) The provision of funds for fishing, gardening and animal husbandry will be dependent on the priorities given to such projects by the Aboriginal communities involved.

answer.para: (1) Earlier this year some 650 firms responded to an invitation by the Department of Defence Support to provide company data for listing in a directory being prepared on the capability of Australian firms for involvement in defence or offsets work. Raven-battlefield communication system

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 7 September 1983:

question.para: (1) Are servicemen who served in the confrontation campaign in Borneo during the 1960s required to have written proof confirming they were ordered to engage in active service in sourthern Borneo.
(2) Are those servicemen who entered an active service zone in Borneo without being ordered and as a result were wounded not entitled to repatriation benefits .
(3) Were those units posted outside active zones engaged in a supporting role; if not, why were they posted there; if so, why are these servicemen not entitled to repatriation benefits.

answer.speaker: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) During the Malayan-Indonesian confrontation, Australian servicemen served in the northern Borneo areas of Sabah, Sarawak and Brunei.

Those areas were designated as special areas for the purposes of repatriation legislation between 8 December 1962 and 1 October 1967. Servicemen who were allotted for service in these areas during this period are eligible to apply for repatriation benefits.

On receipt of an application for repatriation benefits, my Department obtains a veteran's service documents from the Department of Defence. These documents record the Veteran's postings, movements and allotments for special duty. The applicant does not require separate written proof of active service in Borneo.

(2) Under the Repatriation (Special Overseas Service) Act 1962, a person who, although not allotted for special service in a special area, was incapacitated as a direct result of action by hostile forces while serving outside Australia is eligible for repatriation benefits in respect of that incapacity.
By virtue of section 7A (2) of the Special Overseas Service Act, this provision does not occur in relation to any occurrence before 18 December 1965.

(3) As the areas of Sabah, Sarawak and Brunei (which include the waters 50 miles to seaward of these regions) were designated as special areas for the purposes of repatriation legislation between 8 December 1962 and 1 October 1967, all servicemen who were allotted for service there during that period are eligible to apply for repatriation benefits from my Department, regardless of whether they served in an active or supporting role.

question.speaker: Childs Sen B.K.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 6 October 1983:

question.para: (1) Is the Commonwealth Government, in the event of an accident at the Australian Atomic Energy Commission Research Establishment, Lucas Heights, New South Wales, liable for any costs related to the HIFAR reactor, both within the confines of the AAEC establishment and/or any related effects outside the establishment area.
(2) What processes would be required to enable affected people to claim compensation or assistance.
(3) What is the extent of the responsibility of the Commonwealth Government to ensure the health and safety of:
(a) workers; and
(b) residents in the surrounding areas of the Lucas Heights research laboratories.

answer.speaker: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The question of the liability of the Commonwealth or the Australian Atomic Energy Commission to persons who might suffer damage as a result of events of the kind referred to in the honourable senator's question is governed either by workers' compensation legislation or the common law, as appropriate. Whether the Commonwealth or the Commission would be liable at common law would depend on the facts of each particular case. Broadly, where the Commonwealth or the Commission uses radioactive materials, or is directly responsible for their use, any Commonwealth or Commission liability would depend on general principles of liability applying equally to private persons or corporations. With regard to the Commission, I confirm that the Commonwealth would stand by the Commission to ensure its ability to meet any damages awarded against it. Redress against the Commission (or the Commonwealth) would therefore be handled through common law actions (or such administrative arrangements as the Government might decide to set up following an accident).

With regard to personal injury to, or an illness contracted by, an employee of the AAEC in the course of his employment, the employee could make a claim under the relevant workers' compensation legislation, in this case the Compensation ( Commonwealth Government Employees) Act 1971, or could seek to recover damages at common law.

(3) The Commonwealth Government or the Commission, as an employer, has a common law duty to take reasonable care for the safety of its employees. Generally speaking this duty requires the employer to provide a safe place of work; to provide a safe system of work; to provide and maintain proper plant and equipment; and to provide competent staff to manage and supervise the work.

The extent of the responsibility of the Commonwealth or the Commission with respect to non-workers, be they nearby residents or others, is governed by the common law and any legislation that may regulate the conduct of the activity in question. The relevant principles of law could only be usefully discussed in relation to particular examples of circumstances that could give rise to liability.

In practice, in operating and managing the Lucas Heights research laboratories, the AAEC places a high priority on implementing appropriate measures to protect the health and safety of both nearby residents and staff. The activities of the AAEC are conducted to standards of safety which are equivalent to or exceed the requirements embodied in all relevant Commonwealth and State legislation, the Code of General Principles for Occupational Safety and Health in Australian Government Employment, relevant recommendations on international safety standards and codes of practice, and the relevant guidelines issued by the National Health and Medical Research Council. An independent advisory committee, the Safety Review Committee, advises the AAEC on its overall health and safety standards and procedures.

An excellent safety record has been achieved over many years at the Lucas Heights research laboratories. However, to ensure that appropriate arrangements are in place in the remote event of an accident at the Lucas Heights research laboratories with off-site consequences, a plan (APTCARE) has been prepared jointly by the AAEC and State authorities which sets out the procedures to be followed.

talk.start.para: —On 5 May 1983 (Hansard, page 259) Senator Giles asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice concerning allegations that a number of Sydney private hospitals were involved in a scheme whereby some doctors were receiving inducements in the form of low interest loans to refer patients to these hospitals. I undertook to provide the senator with further information when it became available.

answer.para: The Minister for Health has provided the following information:

I am advised that the Australian Federal Police (AFP) investigated these allegations and referred the evidence obtained to the Deputy Crown Solicitor in New South Wales for advice on what offences, if any, had been committed against Commonwealth laws. The evidence obtained by the AFP had tended to substantiate the view that a scheme of inducements had been devised and operated by the management of a company which owns five private hospitals.
The Deputy Crown Solicitor examined the facts and expressed the view that there was no evidence to substantiate charges for offences against Commonwealth legislation.

He advised that claims for Commonwealth bed-day subsidy and claims made on registered health organisations were genuine in so far as the beds were occupied and the patients were hospitalised; and that there was insufficient evidence to establish that patients admitted by the doctors concerned were not in need of medical and hospital care. He therefore advised that there was insufficient evidence to warrant the institution of criminal proceedings.

On 2 June 1983 I wrote to the Attorney-General regarding this matter, seeking a review of proceedings to date and to satisfy myself that the Commonwealth had explored all avenues available to it in relation to possible offences which may have been committed.
The Attorney-General on 9 September 1983 advised me that it seemed that the possibilities of appropriate criminal proceedings in this instance had been exhausted.

This situation will be kept under review, and should any offences be established at a future time, appropriate action will be taken. In this regard, new sub-sections have been inserted into the Health Insurance Act as part of the Medicare package to come into effect on 1 February 1984. It is believed that the Commonwealth's ability to take action will be greatly strengthened by the new provisions.
